{{distinguish|Northern Ireland Forum|Reconciliation Networking Forum}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Use Irish English|date=January 2016}} [[File:Forum_for_Peace_and_Reconciliation_logo.png|thumb|Stylised design combining a [[dove of peace]] and a hand extended for a [[handshake]] of reconciliation]] The '''Forum for Peace and Reconciliation''' ({{lang-ga|an Fóram um Shíocháin agus Athmhuintearas}}<ref name=tearma>{{cite web | url = http://www.tearma.ie/Search.aspx?term=an+F%C3%B3ram+um+Sh%C3%ADoch%C3%A1in+agus+Athmhuintearas | title = an Fóram um Shíocháin agus Athmhuintearas | work = téarma.ie – Dictionary of Irish Terms | publisher = [[Foras na Gaeilge]] and [[Dublin City University]] | accessdate = 20 Nov 2016}}</ref>) was a forum established by the [[government of Ireland]] in October 1994 as part of the [[Northern Ireland peace process]].<ref name="Gillespie2009">{{cite book|last=Gillespie|first=Gordon|title=The A to Z of the Northern Ireland Conflict|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-4dFuaeAlvkC&pg=PA110|accessdate=4 February 2012|date=2009-09-30|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-6882-3|pages=110–111|chapter=Forum for Peace and Reconciliation}}</ref>
==Initiation== The Forum was envisaged in paragraph 11 of the [[Downing Street Declaration]] of December 1993:<ref name="background">{{cite web|url=http://www.fusio.ie/web1/forum/background.html|title=Background to the Forum|year=1996|publisher=Forum for Peace and Reconciliation|accessdate=7 February 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990223194325/http://www.fusio.ie/web1/forum/background.html|archivedate=23 February 1999 }}</ref><ref name="dsd">[http://www.dfa.ie/home/index.aspx?id=8734 Joint Declaration 1993 (Downing St. Declaration)] [[Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (Ireland)|Department of Foreign Affairs]], Ireland</ref> :The Irish Government would make their own arrangements within their jurisdiction to enable democratic parties to consult together and share in dialogue about the political future. The Taoiseach's intention is that these arrangements could include the establishment, in consultation with other parties, of a Forum for Peace and Reconciliation to make recommendations on ways in which agreement and trust between both traditions in Ireland can be promoted and established.
Preparations for the forum were triggered by the ceasefires announced in September 1994 by the [[Irish republicanism|republican]] [[Provisional IRA]] and [[Ulster loyalism|loyalist]] [[Ulster Volunteer Force|UVF]] and [[Ulster Defence Association|UDA]], whose associated political parties were thus invited to the forum.<ref name="background"/><ref>[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/1994/10/12/00006.asp Dáil 12 Oct 1994 p.6]</ref> [[Sinn Féin]] accepted, while the loyalist [[Progressive Unionist Party|PUP]] and [[Ulster Democratic Party|UDP]] rejected, as did the mainstream [[Ulster unionist|unionist]] [[Ulster Unionist Party|UUP]] and [[Democratic Unionist Party|DUP]]. The presence of Sinn Féin alongside constitutional nationalist and centrist parties was considered a significant "confidence building measure";<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/ira-ceasefire-reynolds-says-statement-means-no-going-back-the-view-from-dublin-1445926.html|title=IRA Ceasefire: Reynolds says statement means 'no going back': The view from Dublin|last=Murdoch|first=Alan|date=1 September 1994|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/2505319.stm|title=Another case of talks fatigue?|last=Devenport|first=Mark|date=22 November 2002|work=[[BBC Online]]|quote=Last time the Forum met its purpose was to welcome Sinn Féin into the ranks of democratic politics.|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref> substantive negotiations involving the unionist parties and the British government would not begin till the following year. The British ambassador was invited to the opening of the forum, but there was no other British involvement.<ref>[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1994/dec/01/forum-for-peace-and-reconciliation HC Deb 1 December 1994 vol 250 cc1315-6]</ref> Its [[terms of reference]] were:<ref name="tr">{{cite web|url=http://www.fusio.ie/web1/forum/reference.html|title=Terms of Reference|publisher=Forum for Peace and Reconciliation|accessdate=5 February 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991002163451/http://www.fusio.ie/web1/forum/reference.html|archivedate=2 October 1999}}</ref> :The Forum for Peace and Reconciliation is being established by the Government in accordance with their intentions as expressed in the Joint Declaration, for as long as is necessary, to consult on and examine ways in which lasting peace, stability and reconciliation can be established by agreement among all the people of Ireland, and on the steps required to remove barriers of distrust, on the basis of promoting respect for the equal rights and validity of both traditions and identities. It will also explore ways in which new approaches can be developed to serve economic interests common to both parts of Ireland, including in the framework of [[European Union]]. It will be a fundamental guiding principle of the Forum and of participation in it that all differences relating to the exercise of the right of self-determination of the people of Ireland, and to all other matters, will be resolved exclusively by peaceful and democratic means. The purposes of the Forum will be to provide, as far as possible, an opportunity to both major traditions as well as to others, to assist in identifying and clarifying issues which could most contribute to creating a new era of trust and co-operation on the island. Participation in the Forum will be entirely without prejudice to the position on constitutional issues held by any Party.
==Regular sessions== The forum's structure was modelled on the [[New Ireland Forum]] of 1983–84. It was chaired by [[Catherine McGuinness]], then a judge of the [[Circuit Court (Ireland)|Circuit Court]], and had a secretariat with six members.<ref name="members"/> . McGuinness' Protestant background was hoped to encourage unionist engagement with the forum.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/03/world/presbyterians-in-peace-forum-tell-their-fears-of-dublin.html?pagewanted=2&src=pm|title=Presbyterians, in Peace Forum, Tell Their Fears of Dublin|last=Clarity|first=James F.|date=3 April 1995|work=The New York Times|page=7|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref> It first met in [[Saint Patrick's Hall]] in [[Dublin Castle]] on 28 October 1994.<ref>[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/1994/10/26/00010.asp Dáil 26 Oct 1994 p.10]</ref> It had 41 plenary sessions and commissioned several reports, and subcommittees began drafting responses to the reports.<ref name="pr2002"/> After the publication of the [[Joint Framework Document]] in February 1995, this became the focus of much of the Forum's deliberations.<ref name="background" />
The forum was drafting a final report "Paths to a Political Settlement: Realities, Principles and Requirements", which was leaked to the press on 2 February 1996.<ref name="pr2002"/> It was believed that Sinn Féin was objecting to the report's recognition of the "[[principle of consent]]"/"Unionist veto".<ref name="Gillespie2009"/> The Forum published the draft in its "95% agreement" state.<ref name="pr2002"/><ref name="fprreport">See [[#draftreport|Publications]]</ref> The [[Canary Wharf bombing]] on 9 February ended the IRA ceasefire and, with the continued participation of Sinn Féin in question, the Forum was adjourned.<ref name="Gillespie2009"/><ref name="pr2002"/>
===Obstacles in the South to Reconciliation=== Paragraph 6 of the Downing Street Declaration stated in part:<ref name="dsd"/> :In recognition of the fears of the Unionist community and as a token of his willingness to make a personal contribution to the building up of that necessary trust, the Taoiseach will examine with his colleagues any elements in the democratic life and organisation of the Irish State that can be represented to the Irish Government in the course of political dialogue as a real and substantial threat to their way of life and ethos, or that can be represented as not being fully consistent with a modern democratic and pluralist society, and undertakes to examine any possible ways of removing such obstacles. Several of the reports the Forum commissioned addressed this issue, and a subcommittee was established on Obstacles in the South to Reconciliation.<ref name="dail20000405">[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/2000/04/05/00022.asp Dáil 5 April 2000 p.22]</ref> It considered the reports and made a draft report recommending changes to the [[Constitution of Ireland]], as well as changing the [[Amhrán na bhFiann|Irish national anthem]] and [[Flag of Ireland|tricolour flag]].<ref name="ind435478"/> Details of its draft proposals were leaked in 1998.<ref name="ind435478">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/threatening-to-sound-death-knell-for-the-angelus-bell-435478.html|title=Threatening to sound death knell for the Angelus bell|last=Dowling|first=Brian|date=11 August 1998|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/drop-the-angelus-and-axe-anthem-435502.html|title=Drop the Angelus and axe anthem|last=Dowling|first=Brian|date=11 August 1998|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref> When the Forum was revived in 2002, the draft report was not published as it was felt the intervening events had rendered it obsolete.<ref name="pr2002"/><ref name="dail20000405"/>
===Delegates=== There were separate delegations for each political party with elected representatives in either the [[Republic of Ireland]] or [[Northern Ireland]], as well as [[independent (politician)|independent]]s, with "a democratic mandate and a commitment to resolving political differences by exclusively peaceful and democratic means".<ref name="background"/> Unionist and loyalist parties refused to participate as delegates, though some unionists made presentations to the delegates in the public sessions. prisoners' issues.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fusio.ie/web1/forum/15_11_95.html|title=Forum session - Friday 17 November|date=15 November 1995|publisher=Forum for Peace and Reconciliation|accessdate=5 February 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991001112001/http://www.fusio.ie/web1/forum/15_11_95.html|archivedate=1 October 1999 }}</ref> |- | 31 || 21 November 1995 || {{ISBN|0-7076-2425-8}} || |- | 32 || 15 December 1995 || {{ISBN|0-7076-2426-6}} || Presentation of the five studies commissioned by the subcommittee on Obstacles in the South to Reconciliation<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fusio.ie/web1/forum/12_12_95.html|title=New Studies to be presented to the Forum|date=12 December 1995|publisher=Forum for Peace and Reconciliation|accessdate=5 February 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991105135006/http://www.fusio.ie/web1/forum/12_12_95.html|archivedate=5 November 1999 }}</ref> |- | 33 || 19 January 1996 || {{ISBN|0-7076-2427-4}} || Presentation from the [[Irish Catholic Bishops' Conference]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fusio.ie/web1/forum/11_1_96.html|title=Forum commences work for New Year|date=11 January 1996|work=[[Internet Archive]]|publisher=Forum for Peace and Reconciliation|accessdate=5 February 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991105083631/http://www.fusio.ie/web1/forum/11_1_96.html|archivedate=5 November 1999 }}</ref> |}
==Later work== The [[Northern Ireland Forum]] established in 1996 became the focus of the peace process, with the relevance of the Forum for Peace and Reconciliation called into question.<ref name="Gillespie2009"/> After the IRA restored its ceasefire,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.4ni.co.uk/northern_ireland_news.asp?id=6624|title=Irish Government to reconvene Peace Forum|date=8 November 2002|work=Northern Ireland News|publisher=4NI|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref> in 1997, new Taoiseach [[Bertie Ahern]] envisaged further meetings "on an occasional basis".<ref>[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/1997/11/18/00004.asp Dáil 18 November 1997]</ref> One was held on 5 December 1997, at which Ahern broached the possibility of amending [[Articles 2 and 3 of the Constitution of Ireland|Articles 2 and 3 of the Constitution]];<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/06/world/dublin-says-it-might-drop-claim-to-north-in-future.html|title=Dublin Says It Might Drop Claim to North in Future|last=Clarity|first=James F.|date=6 December 1997|work=The New York Times|page=8|accessdate=5 February 2012}}</ref> after the 1998 [[Good Friday Agreement]] this was effected by [[Nineteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|a 1999 referendum]]. Based on the results of 1996 elections to the Northern Ireland Forum, invitations to the 1997 meeting were received and accepted by the [[Northern Ireland Women's Coalition]] and [[Labour Party of Northern Ireland (1998)|Labour Party of Northern Ireland]] (LPNI) as well as the previous parties.<ref name="pr2002"/> [[Maurice Hayes]] replaced Gordon Wilson among the independent Senators.<ref name="pr2002"/>
Asked about the Forum in 1999, Ahern said:<ref>[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/1999/11/24/00024.asp Dáil 24 Nov 1999]</ref> :I said that I believed, in the context of the implementation of the Good Friday Agreement, it would be preferable to see the primary axis for future island-wide consultation being the joint parliamentary forum and the independent consultative forum, envisaged in paragraphs 18 and 19, respectively, of [[North-South Ministerial Council|strand two]] of the Good Friday Agreement. In that event, while it would be a matter for the chairperson and the participating parties, I envisage a final concluding meeting of the forum. There were suggestions that it be revived in 2000 after [[Executive of the 1st Northern Ireland Assembly|the suspension of the Northern Ireland Executive]],<ref>[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/2000/03/29/00032.asp Dáil 29 Mar 2000 p.32]</ref> and again in December.<ref>[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/2000/12/13/00007.asp Dáil 13 Dec 2000 p.7]</ref> Ahern said at the time, "It might come to that point but there are some other ideas we must try first. If it is going nowhere however, I will consider it".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/ahern-blair-in-bid-to-restart-north-process-379721.html|title=Ahern, Blair in bid to restart North process|last=McKenna|first=Gene|date=2 March 2000|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref> It was reconvened in late 2002 after further suspension of the Assembly following spying allegations.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/2324583.stm |publisher=BBC |date=14 October 2002 |title=Reid set to suspend assembly}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.4ni.co.uk/northern_ireland_news.asp?id=6403|title=Cross-border peace forum is 'waste of time' says Nesbitt - Northern Ireland News|last=McG|first=G|date=27 November 2002|work=Northern Ireland News|publisher=4NI|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref> As Catherine McGuinness had in the meantime been appointed to the [[Supreme Court of Ireland|Supreme Court]], Maurice Hayes replaced her as chairman.<ref name="pr2002">{{cite press release |url=http://www.taoiseach.gov.ie/eng/Government_Press_Office/Government_Press_Releases_2008/Government_Press_Releases_2002/Reconvening_of_Forum_for_Peace_and_Reconciliation.html |title=Reconvening of Forum for Peace and Reconciliation |date=7 November 2002 |publisher=Department of the Taoiseach |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710080237/http://www.taoiseach.gov.ie/eng/Government_Press_Office/Government_Press_Releases_2008/Government_Press_Releases_2002/Reconvening_of_Forum_for_Peace_and_Reconciliation.html |archivedate=10 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Compared to the 1997 delegates, the LPNI was absent while the [[Socialist Party (Ireland)|Socialist Party]] was present.<ref>[http://sluggerotoole.com/2002/11/28/forum-for-peace-and-reconciliation/ Forum for Peace and Reconciliation] [[Slugger O'Toole]]</ref> One session discussed the [[Holy Cross dispute]] in Belfast.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/holy-cross-priest-reveals-loyalist-death-threats-85272.html|title=Holy Cross priest reveals loyalist death threats|date=22 January 2003|work=BreakingNews.ie|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref> The Forum's 2002–3 meetings failed to ameliorate the deadlock in the peace process.<ref name="Gillespie2009"/>
In 2005, [[Mark Durkan]] of the SDLP called for it to be reconvened.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/durkan-rejects-fianna-fail-pact-258659.html |title=Durkan rejects Fianna Fáil pact |work=Irish Independent |first=Dan |last=McGinn |date=11 May 2005}}</ref> In 2007, Ahern told the Dáil, "With the restoration of the devolved institutions in Northern Ireland, there are no current proposals to reconvene the Forum for Peace and Reconciliation."<ref>[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/2007/12/18/00003.asp Dáil 18 Dec 2007]</ref> In 2010, the Forum's €5000 [[line item]] in the [[Department of the Taoiseach]]'s annual [[government budget|budget estimate]] was deleted.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/wrans/?id=2010-01-19.752.0#g755.0.r|title=Written answers : Departmental Agencies|date=19 Jan 2010|work=Dáil proceedings|publisher=KildareStreet.com|accessdate=17 October 2017}}</ref> In 2011, Senator [[Paul Bradford]] enquired anbout the Forum's status and suggested it might be revived as a [[truth and reconciliation commission]].<ref>[http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/seanad2011102600004 Seanad 26 October 2011 p.4]</ref> The [[Reconciliation Networking Forum]] established in 2006 is an annual forum to which the [[Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (Ireland)|Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade]] invites groups which promote reconciliation.
==Influence== The Forum for Peace and Reconciliation and the [[National Economic and Social Forum]] provided a model for the [[National Forum on Europe]] established in 2001 after the [[Twenty-fourth Amendment of the Constitution Bill, 2001 (Ireland)|referendum rejecting]] the [[Treaty of Nice]].<ref>[http://www.forumoneurope.ie/index9952.html?locID=41&docID=-1 What is the Forum?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204102902/http://www.forumoneurope.ie/index9952.html?locID=41&docID=-1 |date=4 February 2012 }} [[National Forum on Europe]]</ref><ref>[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/2001/06/12/00016.asp#N7 Dáil 12 June 2001 p.16]</ref>
==Publications== Some of the Forum's commissioned reports and submissions were published.<ref name="pr2002"/> {{See also|#Proceedings}}

Sexton || [[Economic and Social Research Institute]], Dublin |- |Richard O'Leary || [[Nuffield College, Oxford]] |}
* {{anchor|draftreport}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fusio.ie/web1/forum/final.html|title=Paths to a Political Settlement: Realities, Principles and Requirements (draft)|date=2 February 1996|accessdate=4 February 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991002025634/http://www.fusio.ie/web1/forum/final.html|archivedate=2 October 1999}}

page.title: Government Accountability Office investigations of the Department of Defense

'''Government Accountability Office investigations of the Department of Defense''' (DoD) are typically [[audit]]s in which the [[Government Accountability Office]] (GAO), the [[United States Congress]]' investigative arm, studies how the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] spends taxpayer dollars. Since the GAO is accountable only to the legislative branch, it is in a unique position to investigate the military; no other agency can audit Federal departments with the same degree of independence from the President. However, the GAO is still subject to influence from powerful members of Congress. As of March 2016, the DoD was the only government agency to have failed every audit since all government agencies were required to pass such audits by the [[Chief Financial Officers Act]] of 1990.<ref name="Smithberger">{{cite web|last1=Smithberger|first1=Mandy|title=Will the Pentagon Ever Be Able to Be Audited?|url=http://www.pogo.org/straus/issues/defense-budget/2016/will-the-pentagon-ever-be.html?referrer=https://www.google.com/|website=Project on Government Oversight|accessdate=2016-12-01|date=March 28, 2016}}</ref>
Two examples of major GAO investigations in the 2000s were the audits of [[2003 invasion of Iraq|Operation Iraqi Freedom]] and Defense Department airline reimbursements.
==Major investigations==
===Operation Iraqi Freedom=== GAO investigations into Operation Iraqi Freedom revealed a number of accounting problems, ranging from the mundane to the severe. Pay irregularities were a chronic problem. In 2004 the GAO reported that 450 of the 481 [[Army National Guard]] soldiers from six [[Special Forces]] units had at least one pay problem associated with their mobilization impacting 94 percent of the soldiers. The report found that the DoD's inability to provide timely and accurate payments to these soldiers, many of whom risked their lives in [[Iraq]] or [[Afghanistan]], distracted them from their missions, imposed financial hardships on the soldiers and their families and may reduce retention.<ref>{{Citation | last = Kutz | first = Gregory D. | last2 = Frank | first2 = Geoffrey B. | last3 = Ryan | first3 = John J. | date = January 28, 2004 | title = Military Pay: Army National Guard Personnel Mobilized to Active Duty Experienced Significant Pay Problems | work = GAO report number GAO-04-413T | publisher = Government Accountability Office of the United States Congress | url = http://www.gao.gov/assets/120/110556.html | accessdate = 2017-02-27}}</ref>
[[Procurement]] irregularities included [[Halliburton]] charging the government $5 for hot meals they got from a Kuwaiti subcontractor, Timimmi, for $3 each. In one camp in July 2003 they "billed the government for an average 42,000 meals a day but served only 14,000. In a seven-month period, alleged overcharging in that camp totalled $16m."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Teather|first1=David|title=Halliburton suspends bill for army meals: 'Overcharging' by Cheney's old firm becomes election issue|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/feb/18/iraq.usa|accessdate=2017-02-27|publisher=The Guardian|date=2004-02-17}}</ref>
As the investigation into Iraqi Freedom progressed, it began turning up worse and worse procurement problems. GAO [[auditor]]s caught the Department selling new chemical and biological protective garments on the Internet for $3 each. At the same time, the [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]] was buying identical garments elsewhere for more than $200 apiece. Other accounting snafus resulted in the [[United States Army|Army]] losing track of 56 [[airplane]]s, 32 [[tank]]s, and 36 [[FGM-148 Javelin|Javelin]] missile command launch-units. In May 2003 SFGATE reported $1 trillion missing.<ref name="SFGATE">{{cite news|last1=Abate|first1=Tom|title=Military waste under fire / $1 trillion missing -- Bush plan targets Pentagon accounting|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Military-waste-under-fire-1-trillion-missing-2616120.php|accessdate=2017-02-27|publisher=SFGATE|date=2003-05-18}}</ref>
The GAO found that the waste encountered in Iraq is symptomatic of a wider inventory-control problem. More than 200 inventory-control systems at the Defense Department still are not integrated.<ref>{{Citation | last = Kutz | first = Gregory D. | last2 = Rhodes | first2 = Keith | date = 2004-05-28 | title = DOD Business Systems Modernization: Billions Continue to Be Invested with Inadequate Management Oversight and Accountability | work = GAO report number GAO-04-615 | publisher = Government Accountability Office of the United States Congress | url = https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/GAOREPORTS-GAO-04-615/html/GAOREPORTS-GAO-04-615.htm | accessdate = 2017-02-27}}</ref>
The GAO notes, "Poor communication between services within the Department of Defense and improper accounting results in the disposal of needed spare parts and the purchase of duplicative parts worth millions of dollars."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.house.gov/defazio/102699DERelease.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050406033457/http://www.house.gov/defazio/102699DERelease.htm |archivedate=2005-04-06 |df= }}</ref>
===Airline reimbursements=== A more recent GAO investigation revealed $100 million in wasted airline fees. The [[Associated Press]] notes that the Defense Department spent an estimated $100 million for airline tickets that were not used over six years and failed to seek refunds even though the tickets were reimbursable. The Department also reimbursed employees for airline tickets that had been purchased by the Department. To demonstrate how easy it was to have the Pentagon pay for airline travel, the investigators posed as Defense employees, had the department generate a ticket and showed up at the ticket counter to pick up a boarding pass.<ref>{{cite news|title=Defense Department drops $100M on unused airline tickets|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/travel/news/2004-06-09-pentagon-flights_x.htm|accessdate=2017-02-27|publisher=USA Today|date=2004-06-09}}</ref>
The GAO also uncovered several incidences of airline-related fraud. One DoD traveler used a Department account number to pay for more than 70 airline tickets totaling more than $60,000. He then sold them at a discount to coworkers and family members for personal travel. Another employee admitted to "accidentally" claiming reimbursement for $10,000 worth of airline tickets that had been paid for by the Department.
==GAO influence over Defense Department reform==
===Defense Department responses to investigations=== There is evidence that GAO investigations are encouraging the Department to reform. The Halliburton contract was re-negotiated and assigned directly to Timimmi. And Dov Zakheim, chief financial officer for the Pentagon, said, "We are overhauling our financial management system precisely because people like <nowiki>[</nowiki>[[Comptroller General of the United States|GAO Comptroller General]]<nowiki>]</nowiki> [[David M. Walker (U.S. Comptroller General)|David Walker]] are rightly critical of it".<ref name="SFGATE"/>
These audits appear to have been more effective at prompting reform than the Defense Department's own initiatives. In 1989, the Department began attempting to unify more than 2,000 overlapping systems used for billing, inventory, and personnel. But after spending $20 billion, the initiative was abandoned. Gregory Kutz, director of GAO's financial management division, noted the Pentagon's weak fiscal control over its subsidiaries – the Army, [[United States Navy|Navy]], [[United States Air Force|Air Force]], and [[United States Marine Corps|Marines]] – saying, "The [Pentagon's] inability to even complete an audit shows just how far they have to go."<ref name="SFGATE"/>
===Threats to GAO independence=== Scholars believe, however, that the GAO's authority could be undermined in the wake of a landmark case, Walker vs. Cheney. This Federal lawsuit pertained to a GAO investigation into the Bush Administration's Energy Task Force. [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Richard Cheney]] refused to disclose which individuals and groups met with the Task Force, prompting Walker to sue for the information in Federal court. In December 2002, the court ruled for Cheney.
Congressional pressure persuaded Walker to abandon appeals. Having vowed to "go to the mat," he originally planned to pursue the case further. But according to the [[w:Center for Effective Government|Center for Effective Government]],
The [[Center for Effective Government]] reported that, "Sen. [[Ted Stevens]] (R-AK), chairman of the Appropriations Committee, met with GAO Comptroller General David Walker earlier in [2003], and sources have reported that sharp cuts in the GAO $440 million budget were threatened if the lawsuit was pursued further.<ref>{{cite web|title=GAO Authority Undermined|url=http://www.foreffectivegov.org/node/1244|website=foreffectivegov.org|publisher=Center for Effective Government|accessdate=2017-02-27|date=2003-03-10}}</ref>
The GAO was designed to be independent, and Walker cites several factors insulating his agency from political pressure. In a Roll Call op-ed, he remarks, "To begin with, our location in the legislative branch gives us some distance from the executive branches we audit and oversee. Moreover, the head of GAO serves a 15-year term, which gives the agency a continuity of leadership that is rare in the federal government. GAO's independence is further safeguarded by the fact that its workforce consists of career civil servants hired on the basis of their knowledge, skill, and ability."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Walker|first1=David M.|title=GAO Answers the Question: What's in a Name?|url=http://www.gao.gov/about/rollcall07192004.pdf|website=Government Accountability Office|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=2017-02-27|date=2004-07-19}}</ref>
However, the GAO, like all federal agencies, is subject to Congress' budgetary power. According to ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'', "Walker did say . . . that several lawmakers have threatened in the past year to cut agency funding if it persisted with the controversial lawsuit. He also said the budget threat was among a number of factors that tipped his Feb. 7 decision to halt litigation."<ref>{{cite news | last1 = Brand | first1 = Peter | last2 = Bolton | first2 = Alexander | title = GOP Threats Stopped GAO From Filing Suit Against Cheney | url=http://rense.com/general34/gao.htm|accessdate=2017-02-27|agency=The Hill|date=2003-02-19}}</ref>
It is difficult to tell whether curtailed GAO independence will threaten Defense Department reform. Some aspects of Defense Department accounting have resisted reform for decades. Danielle Brian, director of the nonprofit [[Project on Government Oversight]], says, "Waste has become ingrained in the Defense budget because opposition to defense spending is portrayed as unpatriotic, and legislators are often more concerned about winning Pentagon [[pork barrel|pork]] than controlling defense waste."<ref name="SFGATE"/>
But even Representatives who generally support Defense spending seem to be getting fed up with the problem. Representative [[Thomas M. Davis]], R-Virginia, asked the Pentagon to present 11 documents relating to contracts in Iraq, among them papers that would prove whether Halliburton benefited from its association with Cheney. And Rep. [[Jimmy Duncan (U.S. politician)|John Duncan]], R-Tenn., of the House Committee on Government Reform recently said, "I've always considered myself to be a pro-military type person, but that doesn't mean I just want to sit back and watch the Pentagon waste billions and billions of dollars."<ref name="SFGATE"/>
Supporters of the GAO investigations like to point out the disparity between the GAO budget and military expenses. The GAO's [[fiscal year|Fiscal Year]] 2016 annual budget was $555 million, with "Measurable financial benefits from GAO work: $63.4 billion--a return of about $112 on every dollar invested in GAO."<ref>{{cite web | year = 2016 | title=GAO at a Glance|url=http://www.gao.gov/about/gglance.html|website=Government Accountability Office|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=2017-02-27}}</ref> In contrast, GAO reports show that the Defense Department's 2,200 overlapping financial systems cost $18 billion a year to operate.<ref name="SFGATE"/>
In March 2016, the [[Project on Government Oversight]] reported that, "The Department of Defense remains the only federal agency that can't get a clean audit". DoD sources said, "I think we are on the right track [but] it will take a couple more years." However, "unless efforts to hold the Pentagon accountable become law, it's unlikely that the largest government agency will be able to be audited any time soon.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Smithberger|first1=Mandy|title=Will the Pentagon Ever Be Able to Be Audited? The Department of Defense remains the only federal agency that can't get a clean audit opinion on its Statement of Budgetary Resources|url=http://www.pogo.org/straus/issues/defense-budget/2016/will-the-pentagon-ever-be.html|website=pogo.org|publisher=Project on Government Oversight|accessdate=2017-02-27|date=March 28, 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox book | name = Heaven and Earth: Global Warming – The Missing Science | image = Heaven and earth plimer.jpg | caption = Book cover (2009) | author = [[Ian Plimer]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Australia | language = English | series = | subject = [[Global warming]] | publisher = [[Connor Court Publishing]] | pub_date = May 2009 | media_type = Print | pages = 504 | isbn = 0-7043-7166-9 | oclc= 316432445 | preceded_by = A Short History of Planet Earth | followed_by = }} '''''Heaven and Earth: Global Warming – The Missing Science''''' is a [[popular science]] book published in 2009 and written by Australian [[geologist]], [[professor]] of [[mining geology]] at [[Adelaide University]],<ref>{{Cite web|title=The University of Adelaide Staff Directory|url=http://www.adelaide.edu.au/directory/ian.plimer|publisher=University of Adelaide|date=28 March 2010|accessdate=31 March 2010}}</ref> and mining company director [[Ian Plimer]]. It disputes the [[scientific consensus on climate change]], including the view that [[global warming]] is "very likely due to the observed increase in anthropogenic (man-made) greenhouse gas concentrations"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar4/wg1/ar4-wg1-spm.pdf | title=IPCC AR4 Summary for Policymakers | publisher=[[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]]}}</ref> and asserts that the debate is being driven by what the author regards as irrational and unscientific elements.
The book received what ''[[The Age]]'' newspaper called "glowing endorsements" from the conservative press.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=The Age|title=The sceptic's shadow of doubt|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/the-sceptics-shadow-of-doubt-20090501-aqa1.html?page=-1|accessdate=30 March 2010|date=2 May 2009|first=Adam|last=Morton | location=Melbourne}}</ref> ''[[The Australian]]'' said it gave "all the scientific ammunition climate change skeptics could want."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/sceptic-spells-doom-for-alarmists/story-e6frg6xo-1225700037091 |title=Sceptic spells doom for alarmists | The Australian |publisher=www.theaustralian.com.au |accessdate=2010-03-28 |date=18 April 2009}}</ref> Other reviewers criticised the book as unscientific, inaccurate, based on obsolete research, and internally inconsistent. Ideas in it have been described as "so wrong as to be laughable".<ref name= "ashley"/>
''Heaven and Earth'' was a bestseller in Australia when published in May 2009, and is in its seventh printing, according to the publisher.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.connorcourt.com/catalog1/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=7&products_id=103&zenid=3c05f7db155e1ae050c97e9597f00e44 |title=Heaven and Earth Global Warming... Ian Plimer - $39.95 : Connor Court Publishing, Australian Publisher |publisher=www.connorcourt.com |accessdate=2009-09-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091010120015/http://www.connorcourt.com/catalog1/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=7&products_id=103&zenid=3c05f7db155e1ae050c97e9597f00e44 |archive-date=10 October 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The book has also been published in the United States and the United Kingdom.<ref name="Skinner" />
== Background == ''Heaven and Earth'' is a sequel to a previous work by Plimer called ''A Short History of Planet Earth''. Published in 2001, ''A Short History'' was based on a decade's worth of radio broadcasts by Plimer aimed mainly at rural Australians. It became a bestseller and won a [[Eureka Prize]] in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eureka: A Short History of Planet Earth|url=http://eureka.australianmuseum.net.au/7F923342-9A53-0F79-BF02023316166B60|accessdate=20 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016052918/http://eureka.australianmuseum.net.au/7F923342-9A53-0F79-BF02023316166B60|archive-date=16 October 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, Plimer was unable to find any major publisher willing to publish his follow-up book. He attributed this to there being "a lot of fear out there. No one wants to go against the popular paradigm."<ref>{{cite news|last=Senior|first=Antonia|title=Blunt warning about greens under the bed|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/columnists/guest_contributors/article6725471.ece|newspaper=The Times|date=24 July 2009|location=London}}</ref> Plimer turned to [[Connor Court Publishing]]. The company has a history of publishing books on "culture, justice and religion", including many books on [[Christianity]] and [[Catholicism]] in particular. It has also published fellow Australian [[climate change skeptic]] [[Garth Paltridge]]'s book, ''The Climate Caper'', which likewise criticises the climate change consensus and the "politicisation of science".<ref>{{cite news|title=Ballan publisher in heaven after coup|url=http://www.thecourier.com.au/news/local/news/general/ballan-publisher-in-heaven-after-coup/1553105.aspx?storypage=0|work=The Courier|date=28 June 2009|accessdate=20 July 2009}}</ref> ''[[Crikey]],'' an Australian [[webzine]], commented that the publication of ''Heaven and Earth'' was a coup for conservatives, and said of the publisher: "The conservatives have a new friend in publishing".<ref name="crikey">{{cite web |url=http://www.crikey.com.au/2009/04/20/plimers-heaven-and-earth-a-conservative-coup/ |title=Plimer’s Heaven and Earth: a conservative coup? |accessdate=2009-08-09 |publisher=crikey.com.au |author=Andrew Dodd}}</ref>
According to Plimer, he wrote ''Heaven and Earth'' after being "incensed by increasing public acceptance of the idea that humans have caused global warming" and set out to "knock out every single argument we hear about climate change." Although he does not dispute that climate change is happening, he argues that "It's got nothing to do with the atmosphere, it's about what happens in the galaxy" and that climate is driven by the sun, the Earth's orbit and plate tectonics rather than the levels of atmospheric [[greenhouse gas]]es such as [[carbon dioxide]].<ref name="adl">{{cite news|last=Jenkin|first=Cara|title=Humans are `not hurting' the climate|url=http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,25325285-5006301,00.html|work=The Advertiser|date=13 April 2009}}</ref> Plimer says his book is for the "average punter in the street" who can "smell something is wrong in the climate debate but can't put a finger on what."<ref name="age">{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/the-sceptics-shadow-of-doubt-20090501-aqa1.html?page=-1 |title=The sceptic's shadow of doubt |publisher=theage.com.au |accessdate=2009-05-22 | location=Melbourne | first=Adam | last=Morton | date=2 May 2009}}</ref>
Critics have regularly questioned Plimer about his commercial interests in the mining industry,<ref name="coi">{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,25555783-5018662,00.html |title=AdelaideNow... Why I'd put global warming on ice |publisher=www.news.com.au |accessdate=2009-08-30 | date=28 May 2009}}</ref> but he defends the independence of his views, saying that these commercial interests do not colour his arguments, which are based on pure science. Critics note that Plimer has opposed a [[carbon emission trading|carbon trading]] scheme in Australia, saying that "it would probably destroy [the mining industry] totally".<ref name="destroy">{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/business/items/200811/s2416977.htm |title=Lateline Business - 11/11/2008: Ian Plimer joins Lateline Business |publisher=www.abc.net.au |accessdate=2009-08-30}}</ref>
== Synopsis == In the book, Plimer likens the concept of human-induced climate change to [[creationism]] and asserts that it is a "fundamentalist religion adopted by urban [[atheism|atheists]] looking to fill a yawning spiritual gap plaguing the West". Environmental groups are claimed to have filled this gap by having a romantic view of a less developed past. The book is critical of the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC), which he claims has allowed "little or no geological, archeological or historical input" in its analyses.<ref name="age" /> If it had, the book asserts, the IPCC would know cold times lead to dwindling populations, social disruption, extinction, disease and catastrophic droughts, while warm times lead to life blossoming and economic booms – suggesting that global warming, whether or not caused by humans, should be welcomed.<ref name="age" />
The book is critical of political efforts to address climate change and argues that extreme environmental changes are inevitable and unavoidable.<ref name="adl" /> Meteorologists have a huge amount to gain from climate change research,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/content/2008/s2554129.htm |title=Lateline - 27/04/2009: Ian Plimer discusses his book denying global warming |publisher=www.abc.net.au |accessdate=2009-08-30}}</ref> the book claims, and they have narrowed the climate change debate to the atmosphere, whereas the truth is more complex. Money would be better directed to dealing with problems as they occur rather than making expensive and futile attempts to prevent climate change.
The book differs from the scientific consensus in contending that the [[Great Barrier Reef#Climate change|Great Barrier Reef]] will benefit from rising seas,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/unleashed/stories/s2655036.htm |title=Unleashed: Legislative time bomb |publisher=www.abc.net.au |accessdate=2009-08-30}}</ref> that there is no correlation between [[Greenhouse effect#Greenhouse gases|carbon dioxide]] levels and temperature, and that 98% of the greenhouse effect is due to [[Greenhouse effect#Greenhouse gases|water vapour]].
In the book, Plimer asserts that the current theory of human-induced global warming is not in accord with history, archaeology, geology or astronomy and must be rejected, that promotion of this theory as science is fraudulent, and that the current alarm over climate change is the result of bad science.<ref>{{cite news|last=Akerman |first=Piers |url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,21540128-5007146,00.html |title=ABC scaremongering on the environment | Opinion |publisher=News.com.au |date=12 April 2007 |accessdate=2009-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/environment/cool-heads-missing/2007/04/05/1175366406378.html |title=Cool heads missing in the pressure cooker – Environment |publisher=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |date= 2007-04-06|accessdate=2009-04-14}}</ref> He argues that [[climate model]]s focus too strongly on the effects of [[carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere|carbon dioxide]], rather than factoring in other issues such as [[solar variation]],<ref name="sheehan" /> the effect of [[Cloud feedback|clouds]],<ref name="pl-787"/> and unreliable [[Instrumental temperature record|temperature measurements]].<ref name="pl-787"/>
== Reception and criticism == ''Heaven and Earth'' received substantial coverage in the Australian and international media. It produced a highly polarised response from reviewers, with members of the conservative press<ref name="age" /> praising the book and many scientists criticising it. A ''[[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]]'' columnist called the book "a damning critique" of the theory of man-made global warming,<ref name=Strassel /> while the ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' writer and activist [[George Monbiot]] listed some of the book's errors with the comment: "Seldom has a book been more cleanly murdered by scientists than Ian Plimer's ''Heaven and Earth'', which purports to show that manmade climate change is nonsense. Since its publication in Australia it has been ridiculed for a hilarious series of schoolboy errors, and its fudging and manipulation of the data."<ref name="Monbiot" />
=== Reactions from scientists === Canadian broadcaster [[John Moore (broadcaster)|John Moore]] said it was "widely criticised by fellow scientists as just another collection of denier hits."<ref name="criticized">{{cite web |url=http://network.nationalpost.com/np/blogs/fullcomment/archive/2009/07/16/john-moore-one-world-government-and-global-warming-climate-change-whatever.aspx |title=One world government and global warming/climate change/whatever |accessdate=2009-07-24 |publisher=National Post |author=John Moore |date=May 2009 |quote=book that has been widely criticised by fellow scientists as just another collection of denier hits |archive-url=http://www.webcitation.org/5iQw7vsEY?url=http://network.nationalpost.com/np/blogs/fullcomment/archive/2009/07/16/john%2Dmoore%2Done%2Dworld%2Dgovernment%2Dand%2Dglobal%2Dwarming%2Dclimate%2Dchange%2Dwhatever.aspx |archive-date=21 July 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The ''[[Adelaide Advertiser]]'' stated that among other scientists, "Plimer is all but out in the cold".<ref name="coi"/>
Barry Brook of [[University of Adelaide|Adelaide University's]] Research Institute for Climate Change and Sustainability, who is at the same university as Plimer and has debated climate change issues with him,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.independentweekly.com.au/news/local/news/general/ian-plimer-a-question-of-faith/1495699.aspx?storypage=0 |title=Ian Plimer: A question of faith - Local News - News - General - The Independent Weekly |publisher=independentweekly.com.au |accessdate=2009-08-17}}</ref> described the book as a case study "in how not to be objective" and accused Plimer of using "[[Cherry picking (fallacy)|selective evidence]]". Brook said that Plimer's "stated view of climate science is that a vast number of extremely well respected scientists and a whole range of specialist disciplines have fallen prey to delusional self-interest and become nothing more than unthinking ideologues. Plausible to conspiracy theorists, perhaps, but hardly a sane world view, and insulting to all those genuinely committed to real science."<ref>{{cite news|last=Edwards|first=Verity|title=Climate sceptics ready to storm heaven with earth's geological history|work=The Australian|date=23 April 2009}}</ref> He said that Plimer's assertions about man's role in climate change were "naive, reflected a poor understanding of climate science, and relied on recycled and distorted arguments that had been repeatedly refuted."<ref name="brook-pl">{{cite web |url=http://bravenewclimate.com/2009/04/23/ian-plimer-heaven-and-earth/ |title=Ian Plimer – Heaven and Earth |accessdate=2009-07-05 |publisher=BraveNewClimate.com |author=Barry Brook}}</ref> Brook also suggested that many of the scientific authors cited by Plimer actually support the consensus view and that their work is misrepresented in Plimer's book.<ref name="brook-pl"/> Susannah Eliott, the chief executive of the [[Australian Science Media Centre]], encouraged colleagues to read the book and comment on it, but took the view that "there isn't anything new in there, they are all old arguments".<ref name="Peddie" />
Many reviewers highlighted factual and sourcing problems in ''Heaven and Earth''. [[Colin Woodroffe]], a coastal geomorphologist at the [[University of Wollongong]], and a lead chapter author for the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change|IPCC]] [[AR4]], wrote that the book has many errors and will be "remembered for the confrontation it provokes rather than the science it stimulates." Woodroffe noted Plimer's "unbalanced approach to the topic," and concluded that the book was not written as a contribution to any scientific debate, and was evidently not aimed at a scientific audience.<ref name=aussmc>{{cite web|url=http://www.aussmc.org.au/IanPlimerclimatebook.php|title=RAPID ROUNDUP: New book by Ian Plimer doubts human-induced climate change – experts respond|publisher=Australian Science Media Centre|date=21 April 2009|accessdate=20 July 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090829095234/http://www.aussmc.org.au/IanPlimerclimatebook.php|archivedate=29 August 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[John Veron|Charlie Veron]], former chief scientist at the [[Australian Institute of Marine Science]], said every original statement Plimer makes in the book on coral and coral reefs is incorrect, and that Plimer "serve[s] up diagrams from no acknowledged source, diagrams known to be obsolete and diagrams that combine bits of science with bits of fiction."<ref name="age" />
[[David Karoly]], an [[Meteorology#Dynamic meteorology|atmospheric dynamicist]] at [[Melbourne University]] and a lead author for the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change|IPCC]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSSYD334528|title=Scientists say Australian carbon targets too weak|first=James|last=Grubel|publisher=Reuters|date=8 September 2008|accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref> accused Plimer of misusing data in the book and commented that "it doesn't support the answers with sources."<ref name="age" /> Karoly reviewed the book and concluded: "Given the errors, the non-science, and the nonsense in this book, it should be classified as [[science fiction]] in any library that wastes its funds buying it. The book can then be placed on the shelves alongside [[Michael Crichton]]'s ''[[State of Fear]]'', another science fiction book about climate change with many footnotes. The only difference is that there are fewer scientific errors in ''State of Fear''."<ref name="scifi">{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/rn/scienceshow/stories/2009/2593166.htm |title=Heaven + Earth – review by David Karoly |accessdate=2009-07-11 |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |year=2009}}</ref>
[[Ian G. Enting]], a mathematical physicist at [[MASCOS]], [[University of Melbourne]] and author of ''[[Twisted, The Distorted Mathematics of Greenhouse Denial]]'', similarly criticised what he described as numerous misrepresentations of the sources cited in the book and charged that Plimer "fails to establish his claim that the human inﬂuence on climate can be ignored, relative to natural variation."<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.complex.org.au/tiki-download_file.php?fileId=91|format=PDF|title=Ian Plimer’s ‘Heaven + Earth’ — Checking the Claims |publisher=ARC Centre of Excellence for Mathematics and Statistics of Complex Systems (MASCOS)|date=10 June 2009|accessdate=20 July 2009|last=Enting|first=Ian G.}}</ref> Enting compiled a list of over 100 errors in the book.<ref>{{Cite journal|accessdate=30 March 2010|publisher=University of Melbourne|title=Ian Plimer's 'Heaven + Earth'—Checking the Claims|url=http://www.complex.org.au/tiki-download_file.php?fileId=91|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref>
[[Michael Ashley (astronomer)|Michael Ashley]], an astronomer at the [[University of New South Wales]], criticised the book at length in a review for ''The Australian'' in which he characterised the book as "largely a collection of contrarian ideas and conspiracy theories that are rife in the blogosphere. The writing is rambling and repetitive; the arguments flawed and illogical." He accused Plimer of having "done an enormous disservice to science, and the dedicated scientists who are trying to understand climate and the influence of humans, by publishing this book. It is not "merely" atmospheric scientists that would have to be wrong for Plimer to be right. It would require a rewriting of biology, geology, physics, oceanography, astronomy and statistics. Plimer's book deserves to languish on the shelves along with similar pseudo-science such as the writings of [[Immanuel Velikovsky]] and [[Erich von Däniken]]."<ref name="ashley">{{cite news |last=Ashley|first=Michael|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/ian-plimer-heaven-and-earth/story-e6frg8no-1225710387147 |title=No science in Plimer's primer |accessdate=2009-07-11 |work=The Australian |date=9 May 2009}}</ref>
Malcolm Walter, the Director of the Australian Centre for [[Astrobiology]], [[University of New South Wales]], commented on Plimer's "fallacious reasoning," noting the "blatant and fundamental contradictions" and inconsistencies in the book. Walter told [[ABC Radio National]] that Plimer's interpretation of the literature is confused and that Plimer "bit off more than he can chew." According to Walter, "reviewing this book has been an unpleasant experience for me. I have been a friendly colleague of Plimer's for 25 years or more. ... But..., in my opinion, he has done a disservice to science and to the community at large."<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/rn/scienceshow/stories/2009/2586947.htm|title=Heaven + Earth – review by Malcolm Walter|publisher=The Science Show – ABC Radio National|date=6 June 2009|accessdate=6 June 2009}}</ref> On the same network, [[geophysicist]] [[Kurt Lambeck]], currently president of the [[Australian Academy of Science]], said that the book was "sloppy" and that it "is not a work of science; it is an opinion of an author who happens to be a scientist."<ref name="Lambeck">{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/rn/ockhamsrazor/stories/2009/2589206.htm|title=Comments on Heaven and Earth: Global Warming: The Missing Science|publisher=The Science Show – ABC Radio National|date=7 June 2009|accessdate=20 July 2009}}</ref>
[[Chris Turney]], a researcher of prehistoric climate changes, of the [[University of Exeter]]'s Department of Geography, stated the book was "a cacophony of climate skeptic arguments that have been discredited by decades of research." He described the number of errors in the book as "disturbingly high": "statements that are at best ambiguous and in many cases plain wrong are repeated, figures purporting to demonstrate climate change is all natural are erroneous, time and spatial scales are mixed up . . . the list goes on." Turney comments that Plimer "badly mistreats" the history of the development of climate science, "regurgitating" the fringe idea of [[global cooling]] to portray "recent concerns over warming [as] just another case of alarmism." He concludes that "Plimer's thesis of inaction is a course we follow at our peril."<ref>{{cite news|last=Turney|first=Chris|title=Grievous heavenly harm|work=The Age|date=27 June 2009}}</ref>
Writing in ''[[Earth (magazine)|Earth]]'' magazine, emeritus [[United States Geological Survey|USGS]] geologist Terry Gerlach commented that the book "illustrates one of the pathways by which myths, misrepresentations and spurious information get injected into the climate change debate." He highlighted Plimer's inaccurate claims about volcanic emissions of carbon dioxide and noted that Plimer had failed to provide estimates of present-day global carbon dioxide emission rate from volcanoes. In Gerlach's view, this was ironic considering that the book professes to provide the "missing science" on climate change.<ref>{{cite web|title=Voices: Volcanic versus anthropogenic carbon dioxide: The missing science|author=Gerlach, Terry|date=30 July 2010}}</ref>
Retired meteorologist [[William Kininmonth (meteorologist)|William Kininmonth]], a long-standing critic of climate change theory,<ref>{{cite news|last=Fyfe|first=Melissa|title=The global warming sceptics|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/11/26/1101219743320.html|work=The Age|date=27 November 2004|accessdate=21 July 2009 | location=Melbourne}}</ref> supported the book in a commentary published in ''The Australian'' in which he wrote that "Plimer's authoritative book provides the excuse and impetus to re-examine the scientific fundamentals [of climate change]."<ref name="Kininmonth">{{cite news|last=Kinimonth|first=William|title=Cold, hard facts dispel theories on warming|work=The Australian|date=29 April 2009}}</ref>
The scientists' criticisms were rejected by Plimer, who embarked on a lecture tour following the book's publication in a bid to lobby the Australian government to change its policies on climate change to reflect what he called "valid science".<ref name="Skinner">{{cite news|last=Skinner|first=Anne|title=Climate Clout – Plimer book out in UK|work=Kalgoorlie Miner|date=13 July 2009}}</ref> He said that he had predicted that "The science would not be discussed, there would be academic nit-picking and there would be vitriolic ad hominem attacks by pompous academics out of contact with the community" and asserted that "comments by critics suggest that few have actually read the book and every time there was a savage public personal attack, book sales rose."<ref name="pl-787">{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25552775-5013479,00.html |title=Vitriolic climate in academic hothouse |accessdate=2009-07-24 |publisher=The Australian |author=Ian Plimer |date=May 2009}}</ref>
=== Media reactions === Plimer's book has received "glowing endorsements in the conservative press" according to Adam Morton of ''[[The Age]]''.<ref name="age"/> [[Christopher Pearson (journalist)|Christopher Pearson]], a columnist with the conservative broadsheet<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/1999/feb/15/4 |title=The heir apparent |work=The Guardian|location=London|date=15 February 1999 |accessdate=2009-08-28 |quote=...the conservative broadsheet, the Australian, ...}}</ref> ''[[The Australian]]'', served as master of ceremonies at the book's launch and hailed it as a "campaign document" for climate change skeptics that "contains all the scientific ammunition they could want, packed into 493 eloquent pages."<ref name="Peddie">{{cite news|last=Peddie|first=Clare|title=Heated argument|work=The Advertiser|date=24 April 2009}}</ref> ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' conservative commentator<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/opinion/myth-of-the-young-fogeys/2005/12/17/1134703640220.html |title=Myth of the young fogeys - Opinion - theage.com.au |publisher=theage.com.au |accessdate=2009-08-29 |quote=Sydney Morning Herald conservative commentator Miranda Devine | location=Melbourne | date=18 December 2005}}</ref> [[Miranda Devine]] called the book "a comprehensive scientific refutation of the beliefs underpinning the idea of human-caused climate change" and wrote that "Plimer's book, accessible as it is to the layperson, will help redress the power imbalance between those who claim to own the knowledge and the rest of us."<ref>{{cite news|last=Devine|first=Miranda|title=Planet doomsayers need a cold shower|url=http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/planet-doomsayers-need-a-cold-shower-20090417-aa4s.html|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=18 April 2009}}</ref>
[[Paul Sheehan (journalist)|Paul Sheehan]], a conservative commentator<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australian-options.org.au/issues/options_53/article_ranald.asp |title=Australian Options |publisher=www.australian-options.org.au |accessdate=2009-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090912003716/http://www.australian-options.org.au/issues/options_53/article_ranald.asp |archivedate=12 September 2009 }}</ref> from ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', asserted that "Ian Plimer is not some isolated gadfly. He is a prize-winning scientist and professor." Sheehan continued, calling the book "an evidence-based attack on conformity and orthodoxy, including my own, and a reminder to respect informed dissent and beware of ideology subverting evidence."<ref name="sheehan">{{cite news|last=Sheehan|first=Paul|title=Beware the climate of conformity|url=http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/beware-the-climate-of-conformity-20090412-a3ya.html|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date= 13 April 2009}}</ref> ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'s'' [[Kimberly Strassel]] called it "a damning critique" of the theory of man-made global warming and credited Plimer with sparking an "era of renewed enlightenment".<ref name=Strassel>{{cite news|last=Strassel|first=Kimberly|title=The Climate Change Climate Change|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124597505076157449|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=26 June 2009}}</ref> The British ''[[Daily Mail]]'s'' right-wing<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/politics/all/13392/inside-my-local-nuclear-bunker-the-old-fears-suddenly-seem-comical.thtml |title=Inside my local nuclear bunker the old fears suddenly seem comical | The Spectator |publisher=www.spectator.co.uk |accessdate=2010-04-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605043631/http://www.spectator.co.uk/politics/all/13392/inside-my-local-nuclear-bunker-the-old-fears-suddenly-seem-comical.thtml |archive-date=5 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Front_Page/FD03Aa02.html |title=Asia Times - Asia's most trusted news source |publisher=www.atimes.com |accessdate=2010-04-01 |quote=...conservative British writer Andrew Alexander...}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/4265642/Anti-Americanism-creates-some-strange-bedfellows.html |title=Anti-Americanism creates some strange bedfellows - Telegraph |publisher=telegraph.co.uk |accessdate=2010-04-01 |quote=...including Right-wing British isolationists, such as Mr Alexander... | location=London | first=Anne | last=Applebaum | date=16 September 2001}}</ref> columnist Andrew Alexander called it "the best book on science and scientists I have ever read" and declared that "piece by piece, he takes apart the work of the fanatics."<ref name="alexander">{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/article-1198188/Hysteria-real-threat-global-warming.html |title=Hysteria is the real threat, not global warming |accessdate=2009-07-16 |work=The Daily Mail |author=Andrew Alexander |date=9 July 2009 |location=London}}</ref>
''[[The Spectator]]'', a conservative British magazine,<ref name="spectator-rightwing">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/apr/09/spectator-business-monthly-quarterly |title=Spectator Business cuts schedule from monthly to quarterly |accessdate=2009-08-10 |work=The Guardian |author=Oliver Luft |date=April 2009 |quote=[The Spectator is a] rightwing political magazine | location=London}}</ref> made the book the cover story of its 11 July 2009 issue.<ref name="Monbiot" /> In Canada, [[Rex Murphy]] of ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' recommended ''Heaven and Earth'' as "a wonderfully comprehensive and fearless book."<ref>{{Cite journal|first=Rex|last=Murphy|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/opinions/so-wheres-that-global-cooling-alert/article1230773/|title=So where's that global cooling alert?|publisher=The Globe And Mail|date=27 July 2009|accessdate=30 March 2010|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> London-based banker<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.covertmagazine.com/lakshman-menon.htm |title=COVERT Fortnightly Magazine |publisher=www.covertmagazine.com |quote=Lakshman Menon is a London-based banker |accessdate=2009-08-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090811162313/http://www.covertmagazine.com/lakshman-menon.htm |archivedate=11 August 2009 }}</ref> Lakshman Menon wrote in the Leisure section of the [[Business Standard]] of India that "if [the book] kickstarts an honest debate about climate change, Heaven And Earth will have performed an important service."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/realism-over-alarmism/366048/|accessdate=30 March 2010|date=30 March 2010|title=Realism over alarmism|first=Lakshman|last=Menon|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref>
Leigh Dayton, science writer for ''[[The Australian]]'', expressed dismay at Plimer for having "boarded the denialist ark" and described his arguments, such as his claims that scientists had been playing along with the view of human-induced climate change "in order to keep the research dollars flowing", as "a load of old [[codswallop]]". Dayton criticised Plimer's "shaky assumptions" and "misinformation", describing his assertion that the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change|IPCC]]'s scientists "whip up scary agenda-driven scenarios" as "fanciful".<ref name="wobbly">{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25433327-7583,00.html |title=Denialist ark a wobbly craft |accessdate=2009-08-09 |publisher=The Australian |author=Leigh Dayton |date=May 2009}}</ref>
In ''[[The Times]]'', [[Bob Ward (communications director)|Bob Ward]] called the book an angry, bitter and error-strewn polemic.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article6804961.ece |title=Heaven and Earth by Ian Plimer - Times Online |publisher=timesonline.co.uk |accessdate=2009-08-30 | location=London | date=22 August 2009 | first=Bob | last=Ward}}</ref> He said that Plimer "uses geology as an excuse to conclude the opposite of mainstream climate science", and that it is "hard to work out how and why he managed to produce such a controversial and flawed account."
''The Australian's'' coverage of ''Heaven and Earth'' attracted criticism from [[Robert Manne]], a lecturer on politics at [[La Trobe University]] in [[Melbourne]], who criticised the "gushing praise" given the book. Manne deplored the willingness of ''The Australian'' to "give books such as [Plimer's] the kind of enthusiastic welcome hundreds of others published in this country every year cannot dream of receiving", calling this "a grave intellectual, political and moral mistake".<ref>{{cite news|last=Manne|first=Robert|title=Cheerleading for zealotry not in the public interest|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25380219-7583,00.html|work=The Australian|date=25 April 2009}}</ref> Similarly, [[George Monbiot]] criticised ''[[The Spectator]]'' for featuring ''Heaven and Earth'' as a cover story, calling it "one of the gravest misjudgments in journalism this year" since "a quick check would have shown that [the book is] utter nonsense".<ref name="Monbiot">{{Cite journal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/georgemonbiot/2009/jul/09/george-monbiot-ian-plimer|title=Spectator recycles climate rubbish published by sceptic|first=George|last=Monbiot|publisher=The Guardian|date=9 July 2009|accessdate=30 March 2010 | location=London|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref>
Lawrence Solomon of Canada's ''[[Financial Post]]'' commented that "Thanks to Plimer, the press and politicians, Australia is likely to become the developed world’s third Denier Nation" behind the Czech Republic and the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://network.nationalpost.com/np/blogs/fpcomment/archive/2009/04/24/lawrence-solomon-australia-becoming-a-denier-nation.aspx |title=Lawrence Solomon: Australia becoming a Denier Nation - FP Comment |publisher=network.nationalpost.com |accessdate=2009-09-07 |df=dmy-all }}{{dead link|date=November 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
=== Other reactions === [[Václav Klaus]], former president of the [[Czech Republic]] and an economist, recommended ''Heaven and Earth'' in a [[blurb]] on the dust jacket: "This is a very powerful, clear, understandable and extremely useful book."<ref name="klaus1">{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,25376348-5006301,00.html |title=Professor Ian Plimer's climate change book sparks debate |accessdate=2009-07-15 |publisher=News Corp (Adelaide Now) |author=Clare Reddie |date=April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426233259/http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,25376348-5006301,00.html |archivedate=26 April 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.connorcourt.com/catalog1/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=103|publisher=Connor Court Publishing|accessdate=30 March 2010|postscript=<!--None-->|title=Archived copy|journal=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091030084436/http://www.connorcourt.com/catalog1/index.php?main_page=product_info&products_id=103|archive-date=30 October 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> His endorsement was in response to Plimer's request for the backing of "the big guns", which Plimer asserts is indicative of "a great body of extremely clever and well-known people out there that do not agree with the [[The Sky Is Falling (fable)|Chicken Little]] arguments that are being put up."<ref name="Peddie" />
[[George Pell]], the Catholic Archbishop of Sydney, wrote in ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Sunday Telegraph]]'' newspaper that ''Heaven and Earth'' was "likely to make a huge difference to public opinion" and defended Plimer from charges of being a climate change "denier" because "history shows the planet is dynamic and the climate is always changing." The Archbishop concluded that Plimer's evidence "shows the wheels are falling from the climate catastrophe bandwagon."<ref name="Pell">{{cite news|last=Pell|first=George|title=History teaches science|work=Sunday Telegraph (Australia)|date=24 May 2009}}</ref>
Former Australian Federal Representative and pro-mining<ref name="MMM">{{cite journal |title=Miners Donations |pages=12–12 |author=Mineral Policy Institute |journal=Mining Monitor |year=1997 |volume=June |url=http://users.nlc.net.au/mpi/mm/editions/mining_monitor_vol2no2pp12-16.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050721062136/http://users.nlc.net.au/mpi/mm/editions/mining_monitor_vol2no2pp12-16.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2005-07-21 |format=pdf |quote=Titan Resources donated $5,000 to the re-election campaign of pro-mining maverick Graeme Campbell from Kalgoorlie. }}</ref> maverick [[Graeme Campbell (politician)|Graeme Campbell]] has sought to use the book to get "the other side of the debate" on climate change into schools. In June 2009, Campbell gave copies of ''Heaven and Earth'' to every school in his home town of [[Kalgoorlie, Western Australia]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Sceptics, believers clash over climate change|work=Kalgoorlie Miner|date=13 June 2009}}</ref> Senator [[Steve Fielding]] of the conservative [[Family First Party]] has also stated that his views on climate change have been influenced by Plimer and his book.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/global-warming/tempers-flare-as-scientists-defend-solar-debate-20090608-c0wl.html|title=Tempers flare as scientists defend solar debate|first=Deborah|last=Smith|date=9 June 2009|accessdate=30 March 2010|publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref>
[[Lyn Allison]], leader of the [[Australian Democrats]] from 2004 to 2008, called Plimer the "pet [[Climate change denial|denialist]]" of [[Rupert Murdoch]]'s newspapers, and accused Plimer of "happily cashing in on his speaking tours and his book".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.onlineopinion.com.au/view.asp?article=9426 |title=Plimerphiles: the dangerous delusions of Murdoch hacks' pet denialist |publisher=www.onlineopinion.com.au |accessdate=2009-09-11}}</ref>

[[File:Helen Marot 1904.jpg|thumb|right|Helen Marot was a progressive librarian and labor movement activist.]] '''Helen Marot''' (June 9, 1865 – June 3, 1940) was an American writer, librarian, and labor organizer. She is best remembered for her efforts to address child labor and improve the working conditions of women. She was from [[Philadelphia]] and became active in investigating working conditions among children and women. As a librarian, she worked at several important institutions and helped organize the Free Library of Economics and Political Science in 1897. Marot was a member of the [[Women's Trade Union League]]. She later organized the Bookkeepers, Stenographers and Accountants Union in New York. In 1912, she was part of a commission that investigated the [[Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire]]. She was an active writer and her articles about the [[labor movement]] appeared in many periodicals of the day. ==Early life== Marot was born on June 9, 1865 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. She grew up in an affluent family and received a [[Quakers|Quaker]] education. From 1895 to 1896, Marot was the literary editor of ''[[Ladies' Home Journal]]'' where she was responsible for answering literary queries to the magazine. During this time, she compiled a 288-page reader's guide containing over 5,000 books. Included were some 170 author summaries. ==Early library work== Marot left ''Ladies' Home Journal'' in April 1896 to organize the King Library of the Church of the Redeemer in [[Andalusia, Pennsylvania]]. In September 1896 she worked as a librarian in [[Wilmington, Delaware]] as a cataloger. She stayed at the library for three years. The head librarian at the time, Enos L. Doan, remarked on her work: "She brought to it taste and literary discrimination of a high order—qualities which, in addition to her thorough technical training, gave her unusual efficiency in the performance of her duties." ==The Free Library of Economics and Political Science== In 1897 Marot, along with Dr. [[George M. Gould]] and Innes Forbes, opened a private library specializing in works on social and economic topics. The Free Library of Economics and Political Science concentrated on issues relating to social and economic reform and was greatly influenced by The Fabian Society, a [[socialism|socialist]] organization. It was located on the second floor of a department store on Filbert Street in Philadelphia. The ''[[Philadelphia Record]]'' described the library in its pages on June 15, 1897:
Philadelphia has been enriched with a library distinctively modern and progressive in spirit... The new library forms an important supplement to the municipal system, since the topics of the day and the problems of the industrial and sociological world cannot be thoroughly followed by an institution for the general circulation of books. With its proposed technical classification of magazine literature and an accessible collection of pamphlets and volumes, the Library of Economics should become a powerful factor for civic and social education in the community and Commonwealth.Gaudioso, M. (1992). Helen Marot: Librarian, 1865-1901. (Order No. 1350082, San Jose State University). ProQuest Dissertations and Theses.
Marot explained the importance of the library in 1902: "It was founded on the idea that freely offered opportunities from education in economics and political science make directly for a more intelligent public opinion and a higher citizenship." The collection included foreign and domestic literature. It consisted of six hundred books, over two thousand pamphlets, and ninety-one periodicals. This literature, more particularly the periodicals, was not found elsewhere and thus met a most specific community need. The entire collection was donated by individuals and various organizations such as [[American Academy of Political and Social Science]], [[Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences]], Church Social Union, Civic Club of Philadelphia, Direct Legislation League, ''[[Englishwoman's Review]]'', Fabian Society, Humboldt Publishing Company, [[Independent Labour Party]], [[Indian Rights Association]], Labor Exchange, and Land Nationalization League, among others. To keep up to date with current information, the library collected news clippings and government publications, reports of labor societies, and other similar works. Indeed, a considerable part of the collection consisted of government, state, and municipal reports received from the United States government, the different states, the [[United Kingdom]], [[New Zealand]], and [[New South Wales]]. Although the collection was small, teachers, students, and library patrons found its classified and indexed pamphlets and magazine literature concerning present-day problems to be satisfactory. In addition, the patrons could purchase books and were permitted to check out books when they were unable to come to the reading room during library hours. The library was open daily from 11 a.m. until 6 p.m. and on Sunday, until 10 p.m. The small library soon became "the center of liberal thought in Philadelphia"—a popular gathering place for Philadelphian reformers and socialists. In addition to the usual work of a special library, public and private lectures and classes were given to different associations. Besides being the chairwoman of the library committee, Marot was also on the lectures committee, which were all well attended, the rooms being, in fact, more than filled. The first lecture addressed the topic of "The Economics of Socialism." It was given free on October 30, 1897 by [[Ramsay MacDonald|James R. MacDonald]] of the London [[Fabian Society]] and future [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]]. At the second meeting, on February 8, 1898, Professor [[Joseph French Johnson]], Dr. [[Henry Rogers Seager]], Charles Richardson, and Professor William I. Hull discussed and lectured on "Education in Economics." On March 19, 1898 a lecture on "Economic Education, the Salvation of Society" was given by Dr. [[Daniel Garrison Brinton|Daniel G. Brinton]]. Through her library, Helen Marot participated in educating Philadelphians to social changes and pursued the socialist cause for building a more just and humane society with perseverance, courage, and a combination of hardheaded realism and guileless romanticism. ==Labor and publishing work== [[File:Six Shirtwaist Strike women 1909.jpg|thumb|Six women including [[Mary Dreier]], [[Ida Rauh]], Helen Marot, Rena Borky, Yetta Raff, and Mary Effers link arms as they march to City Hall on December 3, 1909 during the [[New York shirtwaist strike of 1909|New York shirtwaist strike]] to demand an end to abuse by police.]] In 1899 she published ''A Handbook of Labor Literature'' and also conducted and investigation for the [[Industrial Commission|U.S. Industrial Commission]] into working conditions in the custom tailoring trades in Philadelphia. In 1902 Marot investigated child labor in New York City for the [[Association of Neighborhood Workers]] and helped form the [[New York Child Labor Committee]]. With [[Florence Kelley]] and [[Josephine Clara Goldmark]] she drew up a report on child labor in the city that influential in the passage of the [[1903 Compulsory Education Act]] by the state legislature.Nutter, K. (2010). Helen Marot. American National Biography. Available from: Gale Virtual Reference Library, Ipswich, MA. In 1906 Marot became executive secretary of the New York branch of the national [[Women's Trade Union League]]. Marot also was responsible for creating the Bookkeepers, Stenographers and Accountants Union of New York. She was the organizer and leader of the first great strike of shirtwaist makers and dressmakers (1909–10) under the banner of the new [[International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union]]. In 1913, Marot resigned from her work with the trade union league. In 1914, she published ''American Labor Unions'' (1914), a work on the syndicalist [[Industrial Workers of the World]]. She then served on the editorial board of ''[[The Masses]]'' (1916–17), a radical journal. After, she then served on the staff of ''[[The Dial]]'' (1918–20). She was also a member of the [[Commission on Industrial Relations|U.S. Industrial Relations Commission]] (1914–16). Helen Marot lived with her life partner, progressive educational reformer [[Caroline Pratt (educator)|Caroline Pratt]], until her death in on June 3, 1940, in New York, New York. == See also == * [[Caroline Pratt (educator)]] == References == {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * Faderman, Lillian.
