''Red Front'' |abbreviation=RCPI |website=[http://www.rcpicommunist.in/ rcpicommunist.in]}} The '''Revolutionary Communist Party of India''' ({{lang-as|ভাৰতৰ বিপ্লৱী কমিউনিষ্ট পাৰ্টি}} {{lang-bn|ভারতের বিপ্লবী কমিউনিষ্ট পার্টি}} {{lang-ml|റെവല്യൂഷനറി കമ്മ്യൂണിസ്റ്റ് പാർട്ടി ഓഫ് ഇന്ത്യ}}) (abbreviated '''RCPI''', {{lang-as|আৰ.চি.পি.আই.}} {{lang-bn|আর.সি.পি.আই.}} {{lang-ml|ആർ.സി.പി.ഐ.}}) is a small political party in India. The party was founded as the '''Communist League''' by [[Saumyendranath Tagore]] in 1934, breaking away from the [[Communist Party of India]] (CPI). RCPI led armed uprisings after the [[independence of India]], but later shifted to parliamentary politics. The party is active in the [[West Bengal]] and [[Assam]]. The party was represented in the West Bengal [[Second United Front Cabinet]] (1969) as well as in various state government during the [[Left Front (West Bengal)|Left Front]] rule in the state (1977–2011). In Assam the party won four Legislative Assembly seats in 1978, but its political influence has since declined. ==Ideology== The RCPI works toward a socialist revolution, rather than a [[People's democracy (Marxism–Leninism)|people's democratic revolution]], a national democratic revolution or a [[New Democracy|new democratic revolution]]. The party strives to build socialism under the leadership of the proletariat with active cooperation of other exploited strata of the humanity, including peasants, working intellectuals and non-manual working sections of people.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rcpicommunist.in/p/blog-page_26.html?m=1|title=Constitution of RCPI|website=www.rcpicommunist.in|access-date=2018-01-27}} ==Communist League== S.N. Tagore founded the '''Communist League''' on 1 August 1934.Partido de los Trabajadores Socialistas. ''[http://www.pts.org.ar/Origenes-y-formacion-del-trotskismo-en-India-y-Ceilan Origenes y formacion del trotskismo en India y Ceilan]''{{cite book|author=S. N. Sadasivan|title=Party and democracy in India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lJ2KAAAAMAAJ|year=1977|publisher=Tata McGraw-Hill|pages=88–90}} Tagore was a communist leader from [[Bengal]] who had attended the 1928 Sixth Congress of the Communist International, and had stayed in Europe for seven years afterwards.{{cite book|author=David M. Laushey|title=Bengal terrorism & the Marxist left: aspects of regional nationalism in India, 1905–1942|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KoYdAAAAMAAJ|year=1975|publisher=Firma K. L. Mukhopadhyay|page=91}} He toured the continent on behalf of the [[League Against Imperialism]]. At the 1928 Communist International congress Tagore had sought to challenge the role of [[M.N. Roy]] in the organization. Tagore had turned hostile towards Stalin, possibly as in reaction to his failed bid to gain recognition from the Communist International in 1928. On his return to India in 1934 he appealed to CPI to abandon its ultra-left line.{{cite book|author=S. Chowdhuri|title=Leftism in India, 1917–1947|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t_FZCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA204|date=7 November 2007|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan UK|isbn=978-0-230-28804-1|pages=203–205}} Albeit CPI would later moderate its positions after the Seventh Congress of the Communist International, Tagore broke with CPI and founded his own communist group (the Communist League).{{cite book|author=S. Chowdhuri|title=Leftism in India, 1917–1947|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t_FZCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA204|date=7 November 2007|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan UK|isbn=978-0-230-28804-1|pages=203–205}} In May 1934 Tagore set up an 'initiative committee' for the founding of the new party. Other founders of the Communist League included Sudhir Dasgupta, Prabhat Sen, Ranjit Majumdar and Arun Banerjee. Tagore denounced the [[Popular Front]] line of CPI, rejecting the [[Congress Socialist Party]]. In Tagore's view the CSP represented an alliance between socialists and reactionary elements of the bourgeoise. ==Communist League and the peasantry== After the formation of the Communist League Tagore began touring the Bengal country-side, organizing peasants to struggle for abolishing the ''[[zamindar]]i'' system.{{cn|date=December 2017}} In early 1938 Tagore built a peasants wing, the Bangiyo Pradeshik Kisan Sabha, separate from the CPI-led [[All India Kisan Sabha|Krishak Samiti]].{{cn|date=December 2017}} Tagore's BPKS demanded abolition of the zamindari system without giving any compensation to landlords, free distribution of land among the cultivators and agricultural labourers, minimization of revenue demands and cancellation of debts to moneylenders.{{cn|date=December 2017}} ==Communist League in Murshidabad== Tarapada Gupta set up the Communist League branch in Murshidabad in 1936, raising the [[red flag (politics)|red flag]] for the first time in recorded history in the district. Tarapada Gupta had been released from jail in 1935, and he established contact with Tagore's group.''Asian Journal of Multidisciplinary Studies''. ''[http://www.ajms.co.in/sites/ajms2015/index.php/ajms/article/download/1764/pdf_18 Saumyendranath Tagore and the Peasant Movement of Murshidabad: A Study on Historical Perspectives]'' The Communist League preceded both the CPI and the RSP in Murshidabad. The party successfully organized peasants to refuse to pay rents to landlords in the area. Gupta would later side with Tagore in the 1948 party split.{{cite book|author=Bishan Kumar Gupta|title=Political movements in Murshidabad, 1920–1947|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pXluAAAAMAAJ|year=1992|publisher=Manisha Granthalaya|page=174}} ==Tagore in Assam== RCPI was the first left organization to established itself in Assam.{{cite book|title=Party Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K9MsAAAAIAAJ|volume=21|year=1985|publisher=Communist Party of India.|page=22}} RCPI built a student movement in Assam. In 1937 a Radical Club was formed at [[Cotton College, Guwahati|Cotton College]], under the cover of the{{clarify|date=May 2017|reason=missing words?}} and with Haren Kalita as its leader.''[http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/bitstream/10603/67910/7/07_chapter%202.pdf]''{{cite book|author=Susmita Sen Gupta|title=Radical Politics in Meghalaya: Problems and Prospects|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2ks02QzhnAMC&pg=PA31|year=2009|publisher=Gyan Publishing House|isbn=978-81-7835-742-3|page=31}} In November 1938 Tagore visited [[Assam]] and met with a group of students and youth.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA134|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|pages=134–135}} His visit was organized by the Congressman Debranath Sarma. A Communist League branch was formed in the province in 1939, with several of the Cotton College students as its members. Students who became members of the Communist League included Haren Kalita, Haridas Deka, Tarunsen Deka, Upen Sarma, Ananda Chandra Das, Taracharan Majumdar, Gokul Medhi, Arabinda Ghosh, Loknath Barua, Umakanta Sarma, Bhupen Mahanta, N. Buragohain, Khagendranath Barbarua, Uma Sarma and Kamini Goswami.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA376|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|pages=376}} The students would later contest, and eventually win, the Cotton College Students Union through the Assam Provincial Students Federation. Tagore made a second visit to Assam in December 1941. This time he visited Khagen Barbarua at his village in [[Upper Assam]] and discussed building the party organization in the province. Tagore was expelled from Assam on 18 December 1941. The Assam Provincial Student Federation, which was under the influence of RCPI supported the Quit India movement.{{cite book|title=Student Power in North-East India: Understanding Student Movements|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PpGfAAAAMAAJ|date=1 January 2002|publisher=Regency Publications|isbn=978-81-87498-50-6|page=107}} On 2 May 1940 the [[Krishak Banuva Panchayat]] was formed in [[Gauhati]] as the open front group of the party in Assam. Kedarnath Goswami was the first president of KBP, a former Congressman and labour organizer.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA137|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|page=137}} The basic unit of KBP was the Gaon Krishak Panchayat ('Village Peasants Council'). The Assamese folk singer [[Bishnu Prasad Rabha]] joined KBP in 1945.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA145|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|pages=145–146, 148}} In 1949 he became a RCPI member. As the Indian National Congress dominated the tea gardens of Assam and there was little industrial labour in the province, the Communist League instead sought to organize rice mill workers, horse cart drivers and steamboat labourers.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA136|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|page=136}} The efforts had meagre results. Notably RCPI made no intents to build the party in the hill areas of [[Assam]]. ==RCPI and the World War== The party was organized along [[Leninist]] lines with party cells at the bottom of the party hierarchy and the [[Central Committee]] as its leadership. In preparation of the impending World War, the party developed a three-tier leadership structure in order for the party to survive under waves of repression. The third tier was entirely clandestine, prepared to take over the party affairs after arrests of the first two tiers. The party raised the slogan "Not one [[paisa]], not one man for war". On 4 September 1939 Tagore issued a declaration, labelling the war as an imperialist conflict and called on the Indian workers to turn the imperialist war into civil war. Tagore was arrested and jailed under the [[Defence of India Act, 1939|Defence of India Act]] immediately afterwards. With Tagore in jail, Pannalal Dasgupta became general secretary of the party. He toured Assam, [[Bombay]], [[Madras]] and Bengal.{{cn|date=December 2017}} During the Second World War, peasants influenced by the party were instructed not to sell rice for exportation.{{cn|date=December 2017}} In 1941 the Third Party Conference of the Communist League of India changed its name to '''Communist Party of India''' (not to be confused with its far more well-known namesake).{{cite book|title=Society and Change|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c71PAQAAIAAJ|date=April 1995|publisher=Mihir Purkayastha for the ASSSC|pages=1, 4, 36}} In March 1943 the name RCPI was adopted, in order to differentiate itself from the CPI. The party positioned itself claiming to be the sole true leftist party in the country, denouncing all other left forces as ideologically bankrupt. Overall RCPI avoided collaboration with other left-wing groups. RCPI labour organizing was done largely outside the [[All India Trade Union Congress]]. It managed to build a core of political cadres and was active building a labour movement amongst workers at the jute mills in the Beliaghata-Narkeldanga area of Calcutta.{{cite book|author=Nirban Basu|title=The working class movement: a study of jute mills of Bengal, 1937–47|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lU7tAAAAMAAJ|year=1994|publisher=K.P. Bagchi & Co.|isbn=978-81-7074-148-0|page=46}} The party was often referred to as the 'Tagorites' or as the '''Ganavani'' group' (after the name of its publication).{{cite book|author=O.P. Ralhan|title=Documents on Socialist Movements in India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CaWaAAAAIAAJ|date=1 September 2002|publisher=Anmol Publications Pvt. Ltd|isbn=978-81-261-0055-2|page=252}} RCPI differed with CPI on tactical questions during the [[Second World War]]. RCPI denounced the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact]] as well as declaring the Soviet war with [[Finland]] as 'imperialist'.{{cite book|author=Myron Weiner|title=Party Politics in India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xz_WCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA122|date=8 December 2015|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=978-1-4008-7841-3|pages=122–123}} The RCPI fully supported the [[Quit India movement]]. The party sought to develop the Quit India movement into a revolutionary upheaval. Most of the known party leaders were arrested, and would remain in detention until the end of the Second World War. Through the Radical Institute, RCPI promoted dissemination of locally produced weaponry to use against British government forces in Assam. In the "Red Front", in October 1942, [[Saumyendranath Tagore]] wrote:
The conclusions that we draw from the Quit India movement are the following:

First, the utter bankruptcy of the Congress, the party of the Indian bourgeoisie and its total inability to lead the national movement.

Secondly, the complete overthrow of non-violence as a technique of struggle.

Thirdly, the complete exposure of the National Frontists, the legal Communists, the germ-carriers of anti-revolutionary Stalinism.

Fourthly, the rapid revolutionisation of the masses.

Fifthly, the ripening of the ideological premises for the growth of real leftism as a result of the political development, both national and international.

The national revolution in India has definitely jumped over the hurdles of Gandhism and has scronfully rejected the petty bourgeois Congress Socialism which is at the service of the Indian bourgeoisie.

It has thoroughly exposed the legal communist traitors of the Stalinist and the Royist brand. Only the political line of the Revolutionary Communist Party stands fully vindicated by the development and march of the national revolutionary movement.

In 1945 RCPI raised two key slogans in Assam, 'land to the tiller' (''nangal jar mati tar'') and 'one third share' (''tin bhag''), slogans which became very popular amongst landless peasants and agricultural labourers.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA3|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|page=3}} KBP was able to make some inroads amongst these sectors.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA150|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|page=150}} Some Tribal League leaders in Assam, such as Aniram Basumatari and Daben Khaklari, became RCPI members in the mid-1940s.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA168|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|page=168}} Their presence in the party helped it to make inroads amongst the tribals in Assam. ==Independence and Partition== As the departure of British colonial rule came closer, RCPI denounced the negotiated independence as a joint conspiracy between British imperialism and the Indian bourgeoisie. RCPI stated that Independence obtained in 1947 was a false one.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA159|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|page=159}} Rejecting the official process for independence, RCPI began organizing ''[[panchayat]]s'' (i.e. [[soviet]]s) of workers and peasants in order to convene a Workers and Peasants Constituent Assembly. RCPI denounced the [[Partition of India]] as betrayal and surrender to British imperialism. There was a strong Hindu chauvinist trend within RCPI, as alleged by Charles W. Ervin. RCPI opposed the [[1946 Cabinet Mission to India]], which wanted placed Assam into the Muslim-majority grouping of provinces. According to Salkia, through its opposition to the Cabinet Mission grouping RCPI was able to carve out "a niche for itself in the mainstream politics of Assam". In 1946 RCPI discussed a possible merger with the [[Bolshevik-Leninist Party of India, Ceylon and Burma]]. The RCPI delegation in the talks consisted of Sudhir Dasgupta, Tarapada Gupta, and Gour Pal. Nevertheless, the merger discussion didn't go through. RCPI refused to join the [[Fourth International]]. The BLPI discarded the RCPI line of organizing ''soviets'' as a premature move. In September 1947 RCPI and BLPI collaborated to build a United Workers Front to challenge the Congress-led trade unions.''[https://www.marxists.org/francais/clt/1996-2000/CLT61-Feb-1998.pdf Cahiers Leon Trotsky]'', February 1998 In December 1947 Tagore was elected president of the All India Bank Employees Association, at its conference held in [[Lucknow]].Syndicate Bank Employees Union (Regd). ''[http://www.sbeu.in/pdf/Looking%20Back%20PDF.pdf Looking Back]'' ==Tagore–Dasgupta split== Tagore was jailed in November 1947. Tagore was released from prison in 1948. After his release from jail Tagore argued that armed revolution was premature in India. But a sector of the party, led by Pannalal Dasgupta, insisted on turning the campaign of building panchayats into a general armed insurrection. Dasgupta assembled an All India Party Conference in [[Birbhum]] in 1948. Tagore requested to resign from the RCPI Central Committee, a request the Birbhum conference rejected. After the Birbhum conference the followers of Dasgupta began to gather arms and prepare for armed struggle. The developments inside RCPI had an echo in the CPI.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA209|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|pages=209–210}} Dasgupta's view that India was ripe for armed revolution coincided with the position of the new CPI leader [[B.T. Ranadive]]. After the Birbhum conference Tagore, at a public meeting in [[Calcutta]], denounced insurrectional line of Dasgupta. Tagore's speech pushed the Dasgupta group to issue disciplinary action against him, accepting his resignation from the Central Committee. Half a year later Tagore gathered his followers for a separate Party Conference, as its 5th Party Congress, in [[Burdwan]]. Thus there were two parallel RCPIs, one led by Dasgupta and one led by Tagore. Dasgupta represented the majority group in the split. It was sometimes known as 'RCPI (Rebel Group)' or as 'RCPI (Dasgupta)'. The Tagore-led party was known as '[[Revolutionary Communist Party of India (Tagore)|RCPI (Tagore)]]'. ==26 February 1949 terrorist attacks== On 26 February 1949 the Dasgupta-led RCPI initiated its armed revolt. They attacked the [[Dum Dum Airfield]], [[Jessop & Company]] and the Dum Dum Gun and Shell Factory.{{cite book|author=Sekhar Bandyopadhyay|title=Decolonization in South Asia: Meanings of Freedom in Post-independence West Bengal, 1947–52|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vt95AgAAQBAJ|date=3 June 2009|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-01823-9}} At the Jessop plant equipment was stolen. Several persons were killed or injured in the attacks. At the Dum Dum Gun and Shell Factory the sentry was shot. The British manager at Jessup was thrown into a furnace, as were two other Europeans.{{cite book|author=John Patrick Haithcox|title=Communism and Nationalism in India: M.N. Roy and Comintern Policy, 1920–1939|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y3d9BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA81|date=8 March 2015|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=978-1-4008-6932-9|page=81}} Another European was stabbed, and later died. At Dum Dum Airfield a plane was set on fire and seven rifles stolen. The militants then moved towards [[Basirhat]]. On Jessore Road they attacked the Gouripour Police Post.{{cite book|author1=Saroj Chakrabarty|author2=Bidhan Chandra Roy|title=My Years with Dr. B.C. Roy: A Record Up to 1962, a Documentary In-depth Study of Post-independence Period|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-XweAAAAMAAJ|year=1982|publisher=S. Chakrabarty|page=37}} At Basirhat they attacked a police station, killing two guards and stealing 26 rifles. The militants attempted to flee into [[East Pakistan]]. Eventually the group was caught as police reinforcements arrived from Calcutta. A police inspector was killed during the gun fight. Only two of the attackers managed to escape arrest.{{cite book|author=Willem van Schendel|title=The Bengal Borderland: Beyond State and Nation in South Asia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KqTIhTWuAXcC&pg=PA283|year=2005|publisher=Anthem Press|isbn=978-1-84331-145-4|page=283}} 39 RCPI cadres were arrested, including Dasgupta himself. They were held without trial for 4–5 years, and then sentenced to jail. Dasgupta himself was sentenced to imprisonment for life. After the 1949 revolt, the party cast away its line of insurrectional politics. Whilst RCPI acted from underground, no formal ban was placed on the party. ==Assam insurgency== The Assam branch of RCPI sided with Dasgupta in the 1948 split. In the wake of Independence, RCPI and CPI initiated mass peasant unrest in Assam.{{cite book|author=Hiren Gohain|title=Assam, a burning question|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pFBuAAAAMAAJ|year=1985|publisher=Spectrum|page=174}} In the wake of the Dum Dum-Basirhat attacks, the party decided to launch an armed movement for the independence of Assam from India. The party held a conference in Khowang, Dibrugarh, at which is decided to build a 'People's Army' as an armed mass front of the party. RCPI-led uprisings in Assam took place between 1948 and 1952.''[http://cept.ac.in/UserFiles/File/CUE/Working%20Papers/Revised%20New/29CUEWP-29_Dynamics%20of%20Conflicts%20in%20Hill%20Settlements-Guwahati.pdf Informal Development, Services Access and Land Rights Claims – Dynamics of Conflicts in Hill Settlements, Guwahati]'', CUE Working Paper 29 January 2016 Khagen Barbarua led the movement in the non-tribal areas in Upper Assam. The party raised the battle cry 'land belongs to the one who wields a plough, the jungle belongs to one who wields an axe', calling for ownership rights for sharecroppers. The Assam government placed a ban on the party, citing the pretext that RCPI organized peasants to cease payments to landlords and supported illegal felling of trees. In early 1950 RCPI killed Ganga Sarma, a local Indian National Congress leader in Assam, during a meeting.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA278|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|pages=278–279}} According to the government of Assam, RCPI committed 12 assassinations in the state in 1950. RCPI financed its rebellion in Assam through robberies and extortion.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA423|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|page=423}} The government responded by cracking down on RCPI in Assam. The government responded by cracking down on RCPI in Assam. As a symbolic protest against the state violence, RCPI cadres tore down the national flag at different places in the state. In the wake of state repression against RCPI, the party lost influence amongst the sharecroppers in Assam. In the wake of state repression against RCPI, the party lost influence amongst the sharecroppers in Assam. In Assam RCPI and CPI were at loggerheads, especially around the issue of the Soviet Union (RCPI accusing CPI of being controlled by the Soviets, CPI accusing RCPI of being anti-Soviet).{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA284|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|page=284}} RCPI-CPI relations reached its lowest point in 1952. ==Work amongst refugees== RCPI had a mass organization, the Bastuhara Kalyan Parishad, which organized relief activities in camps of refugees from East Pakistan.Anusua Basu Roy Chaudhury/Ishita Dey. ''[http://www.mcrg.ac.in/pp21.pdf Citizens, Non-Citizens, and in the Camps Lives]'' The party also had a separate refugee women's organization, Bangiya Dal Seba Sangathan. RCPI concentrated its work amongst refugees in [[Nadia district]]. In 1948–1949 the RCPI and the [[All India Forward Bloc]] dominated the Chandmari and Goshala refugee camps in Nadia district.''[http://www.mcrg.ac.in/RLS_PML/RLS_PM/RLS_PM_Abstracts/Comments_Subhasri.pdf Comments on Refugee Movement: Another Aspect of Popular Movements in West Bengal in the 1950s and 1960s]'' Prabhat Mukherjee and Amalendu Neogi were key RCPI leaders at Chandmari camp. At Goshala the RCPI cadre Arun Banerjee organized refugee youth into revolutionary politics. The party joined the United Central Refugee Council in August 1950.{{cite book|author=Suvir Kaul|title=The Partitions of Memory: The Afterlife of the Division of India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7dNbD9i1vPkC&pg=PA108|year=2001|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-21566-8|page=108}} RCPI(Rebel) in UCRC and ULF.{{cite book|author=Prafulla K. Chakrabarti|title=The Marginal Men: The Refugees and the Left Political Syndrome in West Bengal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WAscAAAAIAAJ|year=1990|publisher=Lumière Books|pages=76, 380}} In October 1950 RCPI forcefully took control of 175 [[bigha]]s near [[Gayeshpur]] Colony and redistributed the land amongst 350 refugee families. ==First General Election== The party boycotted the 1951–1952 elections.{{cite book|author=West Bengal (India). Land and Land Revenue Dept|title=Report on the Administration of West Bengal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y4O2AAAAIAAJ|year=1965|pages=5–6}} In October 1952, the Assam government withdrew the ban on the RCPI.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-sNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA246|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-32560-4|page=246}} ==Union activism== RCPI was active within the [[United Trade Union Congress]], but opposed RSP domination of UTUC.[http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/bitstream/10603/55578/19/19_chapter%2012.pdf "United Trade Union Congress and Others"] ==RCPI in Bihar== RCPI never gained any prominence in [[Bihar]]. The influence of the party solely included a few trade unions in [[Chhotanagpur]].{{cite book|author=Sadhna Sharma|title=States Politics in India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i0HdDbdKa8UC&pg=PA96|year=1995|publisher=Mittal Publications|isbn=978-81-7099-619-4|page=96}} One union influenced by RCPI was the Hindustan Khan Mazdoor Sangh, a coal miners' union.{{cite book|title=Cahiers Léon Trotsky|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kmRdAAAAMAAJ|edition=21|year=1985|publisher=Institut Léon Trotsky|page=10}} ==RCPI in Bombay== [[Krishna Desai]], a textile worker from Bombay, joined RCPI in 1947.{{cite book|title=Intercontinental Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3plEAQAAIAAJ|volume=8|year=1970|publisher=Intercontinental Press|page=697}} He was elected to the [[Bombay Municipal Corporation]] at numerous times as a RCPI candidate. Desai joined CPI ahead of the 1967 state assembly election. Desai had sought refugee in Calcutta, as he was on the run after his role in communal violence. The stayed with the RCPI there and when he returned to Bombay he founded a RCPI branch there.{{cite book|author=Gyan Prakash|title=Mumbai Fables|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V-3KBsT1YZEC&pg=PR18|date=5 October 2011|publisher=HarperCollins Publishers|isbn=978-93-5029-479-6|pages=xviii–xix}} Another labour organizer of RCPI in Bombay was K.L. Bajaj, who became a RCPI member after a visit to Calcutta in the early 1950s. He joined CPI(M) in 1964 and later became vice president of the [[Centre of Indian Trade Unions]].''People's Democracy''. ''[http://peoplesdemocracy.in/2014/0427_pd/comrade-k-l-bajaj Comrade K L Bajaj]'' RCPI took part in the [[Samyukta Maharashtra]] struggle of the 1950s.''People's Democracy''. ''[http://peoplesdemocracy.in/2014/0427_pd/homage-comrade-k-l-bajaj Homage to Comrade K L Bajaj]'' ==1957 elections== The party fielded 5 candidates in the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 1957]].{{cite book|author=University of Calcutta. Dept. of English|title=The Calcutta review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4BAxAQAAMAAJ|year=1958|publisher=University of Calcutta|page=137}} Khagen Barbarua of RCPI was elected to the [[Assam Legislative Assembly]] in the [[Assam Legislative Assembly election, 1957]] from the [[Amguri (Vidhan Sabha constituency)|Amguri constituency]].Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1957/StatRep_Assam_1957.pdf STATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTION, 1957 TO THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF ASSAM]'' ==1960 Party Congress== The party held an All India Party Conference in Howrah in 1960. At the Howrah conference the [[Trotskyist]] [[Revolutionary Workers Party (India)|Revolutionary Workers Party]] merged into the RCPI.Alexander, Robert J. ''[https://www.marxists.org/history/etol/writers/alex/works/in_trot/india.htm Trotskyism in India]'' Moreover, Howrah conference elected [[Sudhindranath Kumar]] as new general secretary of the party. Kumar had joined the party in 1936.{{cite book|author=Times of India (Firm)|title=The Times of India Directory and Year Book Including Who's who|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vsYVAQAAIAAJ|year=1969|publisher=Bennett, Coleman & Company|page=905}} As per an agreement between RWP and RCPI, the Trotskyists were given five seats in the RCPI Central Committee. ==1962 elections== Ahead of the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 1962]] RCPI joined the CPI-led [[United Left Front (1962)|United Left Front]].M.V.S. Koteswara Rao. ''Communist Parties and United Front – Experience in Kerala and West Bengal''. [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]]: Prajasakti Book House, 2003. p. 220. Two RCPI candidates were elected; [[Anadi Das]] from [[Howrah West (Vidhan Sabha constituency)|Howrah West]] and [[Kanai Pal]] (ex-RWP) from [[Santipur (Vidhan Sabha constituency)|Santipur]].{{cite web | url =http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1962/StatRep_WB_1962.pdf | title =General Elections, India, 1962, to the Legislative Assembly of West Bengal | publisher =[[Election Commission of India]] | accessdate =4 December 2016 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20160305013512/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1962/StatRep_WB_1962.pdf | archive-date =5 March 2016 | dead-url =yes | df =dmy-all }} In Assam RCPI stayed out of the United Opposition Front set up by the [[Praja Socialist Party]] and independents.{{cite book|author=Munindra Nath Borgohain|title=The Assam Legislative Assembly, 1937–1962|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YXmKAAAAMAAJ|year=1994|publisher=Annada Borgohain|page=59}} Khagen Barbarua retained the Amguri seat in the [[Assam Legislative Assembly election, 1962]].Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1962/StatRep_Assam_1962.pdf STATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTION, 1962 TO THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF ASSAM]'' RCPI had fielded 16 candidates in the election.''International Bulletin''. ''[https://www.marxists.org/history/etol/newspape/international-bulletin/ib-v01n17-apr-3rd-1962.pdf The General Election Results in India]'' ==1962 Indo-China war== When Dasgupta returned after his release from jail, the relations with the former RWP cadres deteriorated. Dasgupta had evolved into a Nehru supporter. In the [[Indo-China war of 1962]] RCPI supported the Nehru government, a move the Trotskyists opposed. As a result of the dispute over the Indo-China war, the Trotskyists broke with RCPI in 1963. Dasgupta himself parted ways with RCPI, moving towards a [[Gandhi]]an position.{{cite book|author=Asish Krishna Basu|title=Marxism in an Indian State: An Analytical Study of West Bengal Leftism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TabaAAAAMAAJ|year=2003|publisher=Ratna Prakashan|isbn=978-81-85709-73-4|page=75}} ==1967 elections== Kumar served as convenor of the [[United Front (1967)|United Front]] formed ahead of the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 1967]].{{cite book|title=Swarajya|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xC8KAQAAIAAJ|edition=1–13|volume=13|year=1968}} Anadi Das lost his assembly seat in the election.{{cite web | url = http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1967/Statistical%20report%20WB1967.pdf | title = General Elections, India, 1967, to the Legislative Assembly of West Bengal | publisher = [[Election Commission of India]] | accessdate = 4 December 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160305015745/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1967/Statistical%20report%20WB1967.pdf | archive-date = 5 March 2016 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} During the protests against the dismissal of the first [[United Front (1967)|United Front]] cabinet in 1967, Kumar was arrested under the Preventive Detention Act.{{cite book|author=British Broadcasting Corporation. Monitoring Service|title=Summary of World Broadcasts: Far East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L0XRAAAAMAAJ|date=November 1967|publisher=Monitoring Service of the British Broadcasting Corporation}}{{cite book|author=Saroj Chakrabarty|title=With West Bengal chief ministers: memoirs, 1962 to 1977|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aJcdAAAAMAAJ|year=1978|publisher=Chakrabarty|page=269}} RCPI won 3 seats in the first Howrah Municipal Corporation polls, held in 1967.{{cite book|author=Calcutta (India) Municipal Corporation|title=Calcutta Municipal Gazette|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3RHnAAAAMAAJ|volume=86|year=1967|publisher=Office of the Registrar of Newspapers. Press in India.|page=199}} Md. Shamsul Huda of RCPI won the [[Dhing (Vidhan Sabha constituency)|Dhing seat]] in the [[Assam Legislative Assembly election, 1967]].{{cite book|author=Times of India (Firm)|title=The Times of India Directory and Year Book Including Who's who|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LkQjAQAAMAAJ|year=1970|publisher=Bennett, Coleman & Company|page=335}}Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1967/Statistical%20report%20Assam%201967.pdf STATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTION, 1967 TO THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF ASSAM]'' ==In the Second United Front government== After the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 1969]] Kumar was named Food and Supplies Minister in the second United Front state government.{{cite book|title=Intercontinental Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OwtbAAAAMAAJ|volume=7|year=1969|publisher=Intercontinental Press|page=275}}{{cite book|title=Notes et études documentaires|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hL8LAQAAMAAJ|edition=3851–3874|year=1972|publisher=La Documentation Française|page=76}} The Food Minister had been given to the [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]] in the coalition government, but CPI(M) opted to name Kumar as its choice for the post.{{cite book|title=Now|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QYnNAAAAMAAJ|volume=6|publisher=S. Sen|page=109}} The RCPI won two seats in the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 1969]]. Kumar was named convenor of the [[United Front (1967)|United Front]] as well as being named Food Minister in the [[Second United Front Cabinet]]. After Kumar's entry into the West Bengal state cabinet, the two RCPI legislators, Anadi Das and [[M. Mokshed Ali]], revolted against Kumar's leadership. In July 1969 the two legislators were expelled from RCPI, accused of "anti-Party and anti-[[United Front|UF]] activities".{{cite book|title=Janata|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NDhWAAAAYAAJ|volume=24|year=1969}}{{cite book|author=Society for Study of State Governments|title=Journal of Society for Study of State Governments|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SD0dAAAAMAAJ|volume=3|year=1970|page=94}} The expulsion provoked a split in RCPI, with Anadi Das leading [[Revolutionary Communist Party of India (Das)|his own RCPI faction]].{{cite book|title=Notes et études documentaires|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hL8LAQAAMAAJ|edition=3851–3874|year=1972|publisher=La Documentation Française|page=76}} ==1970s== After the fall of the United Front cabinet, the RCPI joined the CPI(M)-led United Left Front.{{cite book|title=Political Science Review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XOokAQAAMAAJ|volume=18–19|year=1979|publisher=Department of Political Science, University of Rajasthan.|page=31}} The front, which was formally constituted in May 1970, had Kumar as its convenor.{{cite book|author=Anjali Ghosh|title=Peaceful Transition to Power: A Study of Marxist Political Strategies in West Bengal, 1967–1977|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s3EeAAAAMAAJ|year=1981|publisher=Firma KLM|pages= 93, 111}} In the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 1971]] RCPI won three seats; [[Bimalananda Mukherjee]] in Santipur, Sudhindranath Kumar in [[Howrah Madhya (Vidhan Sabha constituency)|Howrah Central]] and Trilochan Mal in [[Hansan (Vidhan Sabha constituency)|Hansan]].{{cite web | url = http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1971/StatReport_WB_71.pdf | title = General Elections, India, 1971, to the Legislative Assembly of West Bengal | publisher = [[Election Commission of India]] | accessdate = 4 December 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160305090722/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1971/StatReport_WB_71.pdf | archive-date = 5 March 2016 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} In the [[Indian general election, 1971]] RCPI and CPI(M) had an electoral understanding in Assam.{{cite book|title=Link|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MmxDAAAAYAAJ|volume=13|year=1971|publisher=United India Periodicals|page=23}} RCPI fielded three candidates in the 1971 Lok Sabha election; two in Assam and one in Bihar.Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/LS_1971/Vol_I_LS71.pdf STATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTIONS, 1971 TO THE FIFTH LOK SABHA – VOLUME I (NATIONAL AND STATE ABSTRACTS & DETAILED RESULTS)]'' In the [[Nowgong (Lok Sabha constituency)|Nowgong constituency]] [[Baneswar Saikia]] obtained 32,619 votes (14.34%). In the [[Jorhat (Lok Sabha constituency)|Jorhat constituency]] Khogen Bar Barua finished in second place with 31,810 votes (17.10%), challenging [[Tarun Gogoi]]. In Bihar, Lakshmi Narayan Singh contested the [[Katihar (Lok Sabha constituency)|Katihar seat]] and obtained 1,193 votes (0.43%). In the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 1972]] RCPI fielded its three incumbent legislators; Mukherjee, Kumar and Mal.{{cite web | url = http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1972/StatReport_WB_72.pdf | title = General Elections, India, 1972, to the Legislative Assembly of West Bengal | publisher = [[Election Commission of India]] | accessdate = 4 December 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160305020346/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1972/StatReport_WB_72.pdf | archive-date = 5 March 2016 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} All three were defeated, gathering 47038 votes (0.35% of the statewide vote). Whilst RCPI lost its Dhing seat in the [[Assam Legislative Assembly election, 1972]], it managed to score an impressive victory against Dharanidar Chowdhury in [[Bhabanipur (Vidhan Sabha constituency)|Bhabanipur constituency]].{{cite book|title=Link|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jWxDAAAAYAAJ|volume=14|year=1972|publisher=United India Periodicals|page=20}} The Bhabanipur legislator was Ghanakanta Boro.{{cite book|author=Sir Stanley Reed|title=The Times of India Directory and Year Book Including Who's who|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G2LVAAAAMAAJ|year=1976|publisher=Times of India Press|page=802}} As of the mid-1970s RCPI published the Bengali weekly ''Mat-o-Path'' and the Bengali fortnightly ''Janasadharan'', both issued from Calcutta.{{cite book|title=Press in India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t9Y5AAAAMAAJ|year=1975|publisher=Office of the Registrar of Newspapers.|page=488}} RCPI fielded a single candidate in the [[Orissa Legislative Assembly election, 1974]].Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1974/Statistical%20Report%20Orissa%201974.pdf STATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTION, 1974 TO THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF ORISSA]'' Sarangdhar Muduli, a trade unionist, contested the [[Sukinda (Vidhan Sabha constituency)|Sukinda seat]] and obtained 478 votes (1.21%)''[http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/bitstream/10603/20308/11/11_chapter%205.pdf The Background of the Political Elite of Orissa]'' ==1977 elections== Ahead of the [[Indian general election, 1977]] RCPI was one of the six founding parties of the CPI(M)-led [[Left Front (West Bengal)|West Bengal Left Front]].''Frontline''. ''[http://www.frontline.in/static/html/fl1812/18120100.htm What is the Left Front?]'' The Left Front contested the general election in West Bengal with an electoral understanding with the [[Janata Party]].''People's Democracy''. [http://archives.peoplesdemocracy.in/2007/0624/06242007_biman%20basu.htm West Bengal: How The Left Front And Its Government Emerged] But whilst CPI(M) was supportive of the [[Janata Party]] in Assam in the 1977 Lok Sabha election, RCPI considered the Janata Party and the Congress(I) equally dangerous.{{cite book|author=Shibani Kinkar Chaube|title=Electoral politics in northeast India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q8U6AAAAMAAJ|year=1985|publisher=Universities Press|isbn=978-0-86131-470-6|page=54}} RCPI fielded a single candidate; Shamsul Huda in the [[Kaliabor (Lok Sabha constituency)|Kaliabor constituency]].Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/LS_1996/Vol_I_LS_96.pdf STATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTIONS, 1977 TO THE SIXTH LOK SABHA – VOLUME I (NATIONAL AND STATE ABSTRACTS & DETAILED RESULTS)]'' He finished in third place with 45,047 votes (15.63%). In the subsequent [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 1977]] RCPI fielded 4 candidates.Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1977/StatisticalReportWestBengal77.pdf STATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTION, 1977 TO THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF WEST BENGAL] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305154628/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1977/StatisticalReportWestBengal77.pdf |date=5 March 2016 }}''{{cite book|author=Bharati Mukherjee|title=Political Culture and Leadership in India: A Study of West Bengal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JYg9LlHn21cC&pg=PA31|date=1 January 1991|publisher=Mittal Publications|isbn=978-81-7099-320-9|pages=30–31}}{{cite book|author=Communist Party of India (Marxist). West Bengal State Committee|title=Election results of West Bengal: statistics & analysis, 1952–1991|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CNeNAAAAMAAJ|publisher=The Committee|page=419}} Three of the candidates won their seats; [[Bimalananda Mukherjee]] was elected from Santipur, Trilochan Mal from Hansan and Sudhindranath Kumar from Howrah Central. Malati Bhusan Hazra finished in third place in [[Pingla (Vidhan Sabha constituency)|Pingla]]. In total the party obtained 75,156 votes (0.52% of the statewide vote). ==Left Front era== After the 1977 election, Kumar was named Minister for Food and Civil Supplies in the first [[Left Front (West Bengal)|Left Front]] cabinet.{{cite book|title=Asian Recorder|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KdRtAAAAMAAJ|year=1982|publisher=K. K. Thomas at Recorder Press|page=lviii}}{{cite book|title=The Times of India Directory and Year Book Including Who's who|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5sgQAQAAMAAJ|year=1978|page=873}} RCPI fielded three candidates in the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 1982]]; Mukherjee in Santipur, Kumar in Howrah Central and Mal in Hansan. In total the three candidates obtained 106,973 votes (0.48% of the statewide vote).{{cite web | url = http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1982/StatisticalReportWestBengal82.pdf | title = General Elections, India, 1982, to the Legislative Assembly of West Bengal | publisher = [[Election Commission of India]] | accessdate = 4 December 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160804205406/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1982/StatisticalReportWestBengal82.pdf | archive-date = 4 August 2016 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} Mukherjee and Mal retained their seats. Kumar lost the Howrah Central seat to [[Indian National Congress|Congress(I)]] candidate [[Ambica Banerjee]]. Kumar finished in second place with 29,785 votes (43.34%).Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1982/StatisticalReportWestBengal82.pdfSTATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTION, 1982 TO THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF WEST BENGAL]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}'' After having lost his assembly seat, Kumar lost his post as minister.''India Today''. ''[http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/coming-rajya-sabha-polls-prove-to-be-a-severe-test-for-west-bengal-political-parties/1/360619.html West Bengal: Seating scrap]'' [[Bimalananda Mukherjee]] replaced him as the RCPI representative in the Left Front government.{{cite book|title=Janata|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WgxDAAAAYAAJ|volume=37|year=1982|page=214}}{{cite book|title=Data India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5H1DAAAAYAAJ|year=1982|publisher=Press Institute of India|page=323}} However, whilst Kumar had been a cabinet minister Mukherjee was named Minister of State (for Excise). In 1984 CPI(M) wanted to nominate Kumar for a [[Rajya Sabha]] (Upper House of the [[Parliament of India]]) seat, but that proposal met resistance from other Left Front partners.''India Today''. ''[http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/coming-rajya-sabha-polls-prove-to-be-a-severe-test-for-west-bengal-political-parties/1/360619.html West Bengal: Seating scrap]'' Kumar died in 1984.{{cite book|title=The Annual Register of Indian Political Parties|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jKokAQAAIAAJ|year=1984|publisher=Michiko & Panjathan|page=256}} In 1985 a by-election was held in the Hansan (SC) constituency, after the death of incumbent legislator Trilochan Mal.Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/ByeElection/Bye-ele-results%2052-95.xls Bye-election results 1952–95]'' RCPI candidate Umakanta Roy won the by-election.''India Today''. ''[http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/assembly-by-election-results-show-a-dip-in-congressi-popularity/1/354111.html By-elections: Changing fortunes]'' RCPI contested 8 out of 1111 seats in the West Bengal municipal elections of 1986.''India Today''. ''[indiatoday.intoday.in/story/congressi-loses-ground-in-west-bengal-municipal-polls/1/348625.html Red revenge]'' RCPI fielded three candidates in the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 1987]]; Sankar Mondol in Howrah Central, Bimalananda Mukherjee in Santipur and Trilochan Das in Hansan.{{cite web | url = http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1987/StatisticalReportWestBengal87.pdf | title = General Elections, India, 1987, to the Legislative Assembly of West Bengal | publisher = [[Election Commission of India]] | accessdate = 4 December 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160305020807/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/statisticalreports/SE_1987/StatisticalReportWestBengal87.pdf | archive-date = 5 March 2016 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} In total the RCPI candidates obtained 118,985 votes (0.42% of the statewide vote). Mukherjee was the sole RCPI candidate elected. RCPI contested two seats in the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 1991]]; Trilochan Das in Hansan and Asim Ghosh in Santipur.{{cite web | url = http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1991/StatisticalReport-West%20Bengal91.pdf | title = General Elections, India, 1991, to the Legislative Assembly of West Bengal | publisher = [[Election Commission of India]] | accessdate = 4 December 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140404202029/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1991/StatisticalReport-West%20Bengal91.pdf | archive-date = 4 April 2014 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} Das won the Hansan seat. In the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 1996]] RCPI fielded Bimalananda Mukherjee in Santipur and Mihir Bain in Hansan.{{cite web | url = http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1996/StatisticalReport-WB96.pdf | title = General Elections, India, 1996, to the Legislative Assembly of West Bengal | publisher = [[Election Commission of India]] | accessdate = 4 December 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160807000235/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1996/StatisticalReport-WB96.pdf | archive-date = 7 August 2016 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} Both finished in second place in their respective constituencies. The two RCPI candidates obtained 105,366 votes (0.29% of the statewide vote). RCPI failed to regain its presence in the assembly in the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 2001]].{{cite web | url =http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_2001/StatRept_WB_2001.pdf | title =General Elections, India, 2001, to the Legislative Assembly of West Bengal | publisher =[[Election Commission of India]] | accessdate =4 December 2016 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20160305154127/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/statisticalreports/SE_2001/StatRept_WB_2001.pdf | archive-date =5 March 2016 | dead-url =yes | df =dmy-all }} In the West Bengal panchayat elections, 2003 RCPI won 3 [[Gram Panchayat]] seats (0.01% of the seats in the state), 0 [[Panchayat Samiti (Block)|Panchayat Samiti]] seats and 1 [[District Councils of India|Zilla Parishad]] seat (0.14% of the seats in the state).''People's Democracy''. ''[http://archives.peoplesdemocracy.in/2008/0601_pd/06012008_9.htm C O M P A R A T I V E R E S U L T 2003 & 2008]'' In Nadia district Asit Biswas was elected from [[Gayeshpur]]-II and Gita Rani Kundu won the [[Babla]]-VIII seat.West Bengal State Election Commission. ''[http://wbsec.gov.in/GP_Result/Nadia.pdf Nadia]'' RCPI did not win any seat in the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 2006]].{{cite web | url =http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_2006/StatReport_WB_2006.pdf | title =General Elections, India, 2006, to the Legislative Assembly of West Bengal | publisher =[[Election Commission of India]] | accessdate =4 December 2016 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20141006185506/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_2006/StatReport_WB_2006.pdf | archive-date =6 October 2014 | dead-url =yes | df =dmy-all }} In the West Bengal panchayat elections, 2008 RCPI won 3 [[Gram Panchayat]] seats (0.01% of the seats in the state), 0 [[Panchayat Samiti (Block)|Panchayat Samiti]] seats and 1 [[District Councils of India|Zilla Parishad]] seat (0.13% of the seats in the state). RCPI contested [[Ward No. 87, Kolkata Municipal Corporation|ward 87]] in the Kolkata Municipal Corporation election, 2010 with Simki Sengupta as its candidate.''The Telegraph''. ''[https://www.telegraphindia.com/1100525/jsp/calcutta/story_12485128.jsp A tailor-made fight by the riverside – In the name of the brother & Didi]'' Sengupta, an artist, finished in third place with 684 votes (12.38% of the votes cast)West Bengal State Election Commission. ''[http://www.wbsec.gov.in/(S(l24js355zejoxp45pini2445))/Municipal/Detailed_Mun_KMC.aspx Kolkata Municipal Corporation General Election Results, 2010]''''Times of India''. ''[http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Default/Layout/Includes/TOINEW/ArtWin.asp?From=Archive&Source=Page&Skin=TOINEW&Continuation=1&BaseHref=TOIKM%2F2010%2F06%2F02&ViewMode=HTML&PageLabel=27&EntityId=Ar02501&AppName=1 Our netas have some nerve!]'' In the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 2011]] RCPI fielded Yar Mullick in Santipur and Kamal Hassan in Hansan. Both candidates were new contestants.''Ganashakti''. ''[http://ganashakti.com/bengali/WBASSEMBLYELECTION2011.pdf Left Front Committee West Bengal – Assembly Election- 2011 List of Cadidates]'' The election symbol of the party was determined only a few weeks before the vote.''The Telegraph''. ''[https://www.telegraphindia.com/1110402/jsp/bengal/story_13800449.html 42 Days to May 13]'' Both candidates finished in second place in their respective constituencies. In total they obtained 107,662 votes (0.23% of the statewide vote).{{cite web| url =http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/AE2011/stat_WB_May2011.pdf| title =General Elections, India, 2011, to the Legislative Assembly of West Bengal| publisher =[[Election Commission of India]]| accessdate =4 December 2016| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20140404205355/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/AE2011/stat_WB_May2011.pdf| archive-date =4 April 2014| dead-url =yes| df =dmy-all}} ==1978 Assam elections== The left forces made significant headway in the post-Emergency [[Assam Legislative Assembly election, 1978]].Goswami, Sandhya. ''[http://www.ispepune.org.in/PDF%20ISSUE/2003/JISPE1203/2003-1&2-12GOSWAMI.PDF ASSAM: MULTIPLE REALIGNMENTS AND FRAGMENTATION OF PARTY SYSTEM]'' RCPI won 4 seats.''People's Democracy''. ''[http://peoplesdemocracy.in/2014/0831_pd/comrade-achintya-bhattacharyya-1914-1993 Comrade Achintya Bhattacharyya (1914–1993)]'' In total 10 candidates ran on RCPI tickets, obtaining 72,445 votes.Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/SE_1978/StatisticalReportAssam78.pdf STATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTION, 1978 TO THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF ASSAM]'' The four RCPI legislators were Md. Shamsul Huda from Dhing, [[Baneswar Saikia]] from Batadroba, Khagen Barbarua from Amguri and Budha Baruah from Mahmara.{{cite book|author=Monirul Hussain|title=The Assam movement: class, ideology, and identity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=szZuAAAAMAAJ|date=1 January 1994|publisher=Manak Publications in association with Har-Anand Publications|isbn=978-81-85445-29-8|page=293}} Whilst Md. Shamsul Huda was elected with over 75% of the votes cast in his constituency, Baruah managed to get elected with just 20.9% of the votes cast. All other RCPI candidates forfeited their deposits. In the assembly RCPI formed a Left Bloc aligned with CPI(M), CPI, SUCI and CPI(ML).{{cite book|author=Monirul Hussain|title=The Assam movement: class, ideology, and identity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=szZuAAAAMAAJ|date=1 January 1994|publisher=Manak Publications in association with Har-Anand Publications|isbn=978-81-85445-29-8|page=146}} RCPI and CPI(M) supported the formation of a Janata Party cabinet with [[Golap Borbora]] as Chief Minister.{{cite book|author1=Charu Khan|author2=Subodh Chandra Sarkar|author3=Sunil Kumar Pal|title=Hindustan Year-book and Who's who|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AXlDAAAAYAAJ|year=1988|publisher=M. C. Sarkar.|page=62}} When the [[Assam agitation]] began, RCPI and other progressive forces urged the agigatators to accept 25 March 1971 as the cut-off date for deportation of migrants. As Assam was engulfed in communal violence, members of RCPI and other left parties were killed or maimed.''Frontline''. ''[http://www.frontline.in/static/html/fl2717/stories/20100827271704100.htm Fretful wait]'' The popular support for RCPI and other left parties declined sharply as they had opposed the Assam agitation. ==RCPI in Assam after the Assam agitation== As of 1981 RCPI was part of the Left Democratic Alliance (along with CPI(M), CPI and SUCI).''India Today''. ''[http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/nellie-massacre-assams-image-as-multi-cultural-and-secular-state-lay-shattered/1/371416.html Assam: A state ravaged]'' In April 1984 RCPI joined a convention of opposition parties (along with CPI, Congress (S) and the Janata Party), a move which side-lined the CPI(M). The April 1984 opposition convention used a language largely supportive of the Assam agitation.{{cite book|author=P. S. Dutta|title=Ethnic movements in poly-cultural Assam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CkpuAAAAMAAJ|year=1990|publisher=Har-Anand Publications in association with Vikas Pub. House|page=216}} RCPI fielded a single candidate in the [[Indian general election, 1996]]; [[Baneswar Saikia]] in the [[Nowgong (Lok Sabha constituency)|Nowgong constituency]].Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/LS_1996/Vol_I_LS_96.pdf STATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTIONS, 1996 TO THE 11th LOK SABHA – VOLUME I (NATIONAL AND STATE ABSTRACTS & DETAILED RESULTS)]'' He obtained 1,803 votes (0.25%). As of 1996 Baneswar Saikia served as the RCPI general secretary.{{cite book|author=Arupjyoti Saikia|title=A Century of Protests: Peasant Politics in Assam Since 1900|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QcNcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT460|date=12 August 2015|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-317-32559-8|page=460}} RCPI fielded two candidates in the [[Indian general election, 1998]]; Abdur Rashid in the [[Kaliabor (Lok Sabha constituency)|Kaliabor constituency]] and Padma Kamal Phukon in the [[Jorhat (Lok Sabha constituency)|Jorhat constituency]].Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/LS_1998/Vol_I_LS_98.pdf STATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTIONS, 1998 TO THE 12th LOK SABHA – VOLUME I (NATIONAL AND STATE ABSTRACTS & DETAILED RESULTS)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140718181833/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/LS_1998/Vol_I_LS_98.pdf |date=18 July 2014 }}'' In Kaliabor RCPI obtained 2,778 votes (0.43%) and in Jorhat the party obtained 1,642 votes (0.49%). RCPI fielded a single candidate in the [[Indian general election, 1999]]; [[Baneswar Saikia]] in the [[Kaliabor (Lok Sabha constituency)|Kaliabor constituency]].Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/LS_1999/Vol_I_LS_99.pdf STATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTIONS, 1999 TO THE 13th LOK SABHA – VOLUME I (NATIONAL AND STATE ABSTRACTS & DETAILED RESULTS)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140718183222/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/statisticalreports/LS_1999/Vol_I_LS_99.pdf |date=18 July 2014 }}'' He obtained 1,516 votes (0.20%). RCPI joined the [[Nationalist Congress Party]]-led Regional Democratic Alliance ahead of the [[Assam Legislative Assembly election, 2001]]. RCPI fielded a single candidate in the [[Indian general election, 2004]]; Raj Kumar Dowara in the [[Jorhat (Lok Sabha constituency)|Jorhat constituency]].Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/StatisticalReports/LS_2004/Vol_I_LS_2004.pdf STATISTICAL REPORT ON GENERAL ELECTIONS, 2004 TO THE 14th LOK SABHA – VOLUME I (NATIONAL AND STATE ABSTRACTS & DETAILED RESULTS)]'' He finished in fifth place with 16,691. RCPI fielded a single candidate in the [[Indian general election, 2009]]; Ambu Bora (then aged 78) in the [[Gauhati (Lok Sabha constituency)|Gauhati constituency]].Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/archiveofge2009/Stats/VOLI/25_ConstituencyWiseDetailedResult.pdf 25 – CONSTITUENCY WISE DETAILED RESULTS]'' Bora received 7,788 votes (0.7% of the votes in the constituency). ==Later period== In the Kolkata Municipal Corporation, 2015 RCPI again contested ward 87 with Tarun Basu as its candidate.Kolkata24x7. [https://www.kolkata24x7.com/municipal-elaction-boro-eight.html পুরভোটে বরো আট: মোদী ম্যাজিক সরাতে মমতার কার্ড]''Ganashakti''. ''[http://ganashakti.com/english/news/details/8188 Kolkata Municipal Corporation election 2015 LF announced candidate lsit]'' ==Leadership== Paramesh Das was the Assam state secretary of RCPI.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sentinelassam.com/ghy_city/story.php?sec=1&subsec=0&id=252557&dtP=2016-09-25&ppr=1#.WGZG7jMclG8|title=The Sentinel|website=www.sentinelassam.com|access-date=30 December 2016}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Subhas Roy is the West Bengal State Secretary of the party.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rcpicommunist.in/p/contact-us.html|title=Contact Us|website=www.rcpicommunist.in|access-date=2018-10-30}} On the 28th day of October 2018, an Organising State ￼Committee was forme in Kerala, under the secretaryship of Dipin Thekkepuram.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rcpicommunist.in/2018/10/organising-committee-of-rcpi-formed-in.html|title=Organising Committee of the RCPI formed in Kerala|website=www.rcpicommunist.in|access-date=2018-10-30}} [[Biren Deka]] is the Secretary of the Central Committee of the party. ==2016 elections== As per the second list of Left Front candidates for the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 2016]], released in March 2016, RCPI fielded Sanjoy Basu, a [[Calcutta High Court]] lawyer, in the Santipur seat and Kamal Hassan in the Hansan seat.''The Telegraph''. ''[https://www.telegraphindia.com/1160312/jsp/bengal/story_74123.jsp Cadres spoil Buddha lunch]''''Ganashakti''. [http://ganashakti.com/bengali/current_news_details.php?news_id=613 "আরো ৮৫ আসনে প্রার্থী ঘোষণা বামফ্রন্টের"] After a period of vacillation RCPI endorsed the Left Front-Congress electoral understanding ahead of the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly election, 2016]], although the agreement would mean no seats for RCPI to contest.''Anandabazaar Patrika''. [http://www.anandabazar.com/elections/west-bengal/state-election-news/rcpi-with-congress-1.350335 "কংগ্রেসের পাশে আরসিপিআই-ও"] Hassan's candidature was unofficially withdrawn in favour of the Indian National Congress after the prescribed date for withdrawal of nominations.Prasar Bharati. ''[http://newsonair.nic.in/WB-IT.pdf West Bengal Assembly Elections 2016 Backgrounder] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161228200035/http://newsonair.nic.in/WB-IT.pdf |date=28 December 2016 }}'' Kamal Hassan obtained 751 votes (0.4%).Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/archiveofge2016/10-Detailed%20Reportwest.pdf Detailed Report]'' Basu's nomination had been withdrawn prior to the prescribed date. RCPI joined the six-party United Left ahead of the [[Assam Legislative Assembly election, 2016]].''First Post''. ''[http://www.firstpost.com/politics/assam-election-defeating-corrupt-congress-communal-bjp-essential-says-cpm-2688858.html Assam election: Defeating 'corrupt' Congress, 'communal' BJP essential, says CPM]'' RCPI contested the Dhing and Mahmara seats''The Sentinel''. ''[http://www.sentinelassam.com/mainnews/story.php?sec=1&subsec=0&id=259702&dtP=2016-03-27&ppr=1 Left parties to field 59 candidates in Assam]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}''''People's Democracy''. ''[http://peoplesdemocracy.in/2016/0515_pd/assam-assembly-elections-close-fight-between-congress-bjp ASSAM: Assembly Elections: Close Fight between Congress & BJP]'' RCPI candidate Jamanur Rahman in Dhing obtained 737 votes (0.43%) and Nityananda Gogoi in Mahmara obtained 448 votes (0.43%).Election Commission of India. ''[http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/archiveofge2016/10-DETAILED%20RESULTS.pdf Detailed Results]'' The party has since joined the 11-party Left-Democratic Manch, Assam.''People's Democracy''. ''[http://peoplesdemocracy.in/2016/0731_pd/left-democratic-manch-opposes-privatisation-assam%E2%80%99s-oilfields Left Democratic Manch Opposes Privatisation of Assam’s Oilfields]'' As of 2016 LDMA demanded that 24 March 1971, be chosen as the base year for deportation of foreigners from Assam.''The Telegraph''. ''[http://www.telegraphindia.com/1161025/jsp/northeast/story_115398.jsp Muslim migrants the problem: BJP]'' == Mass Organisations == * '''Students' Wings''': **Assam Provincial Students' Federation (APSF) (till 1949) ** Progressive Students' Federation of India (PSFI) * '''Youth Wing''': [[Progressive Youth Federation of India]] (PYFI) * '''Peasants' Wing''': Krishak Panchayat * '''Women's Wing''': Xodou Axom Pragati Nari Sangha (সদৌ অসম প্ৰগতি নাৰী সংঘ) == Leaders == * [[Saumyendranath Tagore]] * [[Bishnu Prasad Rabha]] * Khagen Barbarua * [[Baneswar Saikia]] * [[Biren Deka]] * Harakanta Das * Mihir Bain * Tarunsen Deka * Mohan Hazarika *Sudhindranath Kumar *Bimalananda Mukherjee ==External links== *[http://banglapedia.search.com.bd/HT/T_0022.htm Tagore, Soumyendranath (1901–1974)] *[http://www.marxists.org/history/etol/writers/alex/works/in_trot/india.htm Trotskyism in India] by Robert Alexander * [http://www.rcpicommunist.in/p/saumyendranath-tagore.html Writings of Saumyendranath Tagore] ==References== {{reflist|3}} [[Category:Terrorism in India]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1934]] [[Category:Revolutionary Communist Party of India|*]] [[Category:Communist Party of India breakaway groups]] [[Category:1934 establishments in India]]
